reviewText: Yep, they are all here, all the action stars of the 80;s and 90's. I was hoping someone could put all of them together for one big movie and Stallone did it! It is one wild ride from beginning to end with everything you expect from the 3 major stars, Stallone, Schwartznegger and Willis. Yes you will hear "I'll be back" and you will see "Lone Wolfe Mcquade" and terminator jokes will be made as will burning towers. There will be explosions, fights and gun battles as expected... you get it BECAUSE you expect it and that is the beauty of this movie. It doesn't take itself too seriously but you also learn more about the team and the way they interact with one another makes you believe these are men that have seen and done too much together to take each other for granted but will tear each other apart jokingly and enjoy it. Tragedy sends the team after a cold blooded killer played by Van Damme after he takes a box they were sent to retrieve. Saving a village in the process is just part of the journey for vengeance and falls into place wonderfully in the story line.  Liam Hemsworth is great as the newbie and shows why he will follow in his brothers footsteps. The kid is a great actor and falls right in place with this great cast. There is also a sense of sadness because you know this show is the last and only time you will see these great men of action together but take heart, there is already talk about a 3rd EXPENDABLES....CAN'T WAIT!!!
Title: N/A

reviewText: The actor line up here is amazing no one can argue with that.  Its your typical man film, explosions, fights etc.  Honestly its the best action film I recon you can watch.  But, me personally, I'm just a bit sick of these story-less action films.  This film knows what it is though, and certain people showing up randomly at key times to "save the day" with zero explanation is not even attempted to be hidden here.  If you like things blowing up, a mindless action flick, and have a great sound system then go for it, you wont be dissapointed.  Just dont go looking for a fantastic story that you will remember a week later.
summary: The best action movie that you can watch, if you like action movies

reviewText: Although it's nice to see all the guys back and hanging out together it's also kinda sad because, in all honesty, the Expendables movies are not that well done. The witty banter is not that witty, the action is not that spectacular, and the overuse of CGI blood is not effective and is distracting. I don't want to see artificially muscled seniors pathetically tossing out the one liners they made famous years ago, I want to see them make new movies with new classic one liners. This blast from the past feels more like a blast from between the butt cheeks.
summary: You really can't go home again.

reviewText: I gave this movie three stars! And I mean it! Nothing short of three stars!! This has some of the worst best, best worst acting I've ever seen. And the diamond drill bit drilling machine!! Who else but Sly can afford to throw one of those in to his movies? And those sexy boy black outfits. Oh, so sensual. What a bunch of great guys. Killing, maiming, looting, exploding and snapping off snarky one liners... All in the name of Justice! American Style! Two points if you can can guess, Who'll Be Back! Well He is!! And the poor king cobra, who suffered through five days of agonizing torture, after he made the Ultimate Mistake of biting the One Person in the movie who, well, if you can't figure out who I'm talking about, you're not going to have much fun here. Really, after fifteen minutes, the real amazement I felt came while watching Sly ticker tape lines off his mouth like he was getting paid a million bucks a second- didn't matter just how dumb the dialogue was, he just had to stand and deliver. Get the damn scene over with and the way you do that, is you say this here line of dialogue and then, We get to move on to the Next Scene, and that's how you make the fkkn movie. Move along now. Simply amazing. I mean it. Sly stands there and, for an actor, he's in some bizarro zen space where what his dialogue partner says almost doesn't even seem to matter. It's like, you can see the crawl just below his face, (I'm waitin' for you to finish your dialogue so we can get to the next scene) It's almost like he occupies the dialogue himself, because everything is so prescribed. Amazing.
summary: One inch short of Mel Brooks

reviewText: Who doesn't love all the movies all these action-movie giants have starred in over the years?? Most any of these guys have carried whole movies by themselves in the past, so it's pretty cool to see them all together in one movie, wise-cracking each other with funny one-liners like bunch of brothers!The actual plot of the movie is just OK...not much to it. Clearly this movie is more of a vehicle to pay tribute to all the great action stars of the '80's and '90's...at least that's how I view it. There just isn't enough "movie to go around" to really make good use of all the stars...lol. Just seeing how they interact with each other is the real entertainment value, for me. Pretty good fight scenes, but again, not enough to go around. :-)One reviewer makes fun of the amount of total plastic surgery performed amonst all the cast, who he called "aging movie stars." Well, I'd be fine looking like Van Damme or Stallone when I'm their age! And BTW, what young, hulking, hotshot actor these days is there for the old guard action stars to pass the action-hero torch to?? Who has the charisma and style (even if most of them aren't top-notch actors...lol) these days that these guys have? Again, I look at this movie as a tribute to all the great 80's action movies, which, thanks to technology, we're all able to still enjoy in the form of DVD and Blu Ray!So yeah, not a real in-depth storyline to this movie, but there's still plenty of action and mega-macho attitude to satisfy anyone! Some think this sequel is better than the first, but I think the first one is better, to be honest. It had more character development, a better storyline that wasn't so rushed, and the fight scenes were better. Still, though, the sequel is fun to watch, so I still recommend it for fans of the first movie.
summary: More mindless machismoism...and a lot of fun!!

reviewText: ...this was not thoughtful. It isn't relevant. It isn't Oscar worthy. It isn't going to make you wake up and change your life or want to change the world. It might make you want to lift weights, get buff and learn some martial arts moves, but other than that, it isn't life changing.What this movie is is fun.It is an old-time shoot 'em up, kill the bad guys, we're the good guys movie. Period. The action is non-stop. The dialog is laughable, but they meant for it to be. Sylvester Stallone and his buddies are having fun with their respective legacies and if you've watched "Rambo" and "Die Hard" and "Terminator", et cetera, then you will recognize a lot of this action and dialog. That is what makes it fun. These guys aren't done. They're not dead and they still have something to give audiences. While this isn't even the best action-flick I've ever seen, the nostalgia for what these actors have given us in the past wins the day.I have to give a nod to Liam Hemsworth. He did a good job in this movie. I wish there had been more of him. I've only seen him in the "Hunger Games" movies and "The Last Song" (which should be expunged from all record. Every copy of the movie and book should be confiscated, burned and the memory of it all should be burned out of our memories. Worst. Movie. Ever.) Needless to say, I haven't been a fan, but he's good in this, and cute, and affable.The best moments of the movie belong to Chuck Norris. I wish I could have seen this in the theater because I have a feeling that the reaction would have been worth it! I know it was a hit at my house. It is so sad that the man cannot act, but he did a great job being Chuck Norris in this movie.I was surprised at the lack of foul language. There were words, yes, but nothing on the scale of what you'd see in most movies of this type, or even on cable. Not a clean movie, but not so foul that you can't filter. I appreciate that. As I said before, the dialog was laughable, but it wasn't so filled with F*bombs that it made the movie experience miserable.This is an action flick. There are plenty of fights, plenty of guns, plenty of blood. But I really think the whole thing was somehow toned down. I had to laugh. Of course, the bad guys can't shoot for nothing. When the good guys shoot, the bad guys just fall down. The stunt men must have had to learn how to fall badly. I've seen worse blood baths on TV and in the movies. This movie isn't for kids, but older teens and adults will not be turned off by blood and gore.Sylvester Stallone knows a good thing when he's got it. There is an Expendables 3 in post production and an Expendables 4 in pre-production. I'm looking forward to it. I will make a point to rent them when they come out on DVD. I don't live near a movie theater, so that isn't a judgment about seeing it in the theater vs. renting on DVD. It's that way with all movies.For whatever reason, Amazon has me reviewing the HD version of the movie. I can't stream HD. I rent in SD. I do not own this film yet. I watched it for free on Amazon Prime in SD. If you need a technical review of that streaming process, the video and the sound quality of HD, I can't give that to you. This review of about content only.This movie is Fun. It did what it was intended to do. It entertained me, my family and some of my kids' friends for the duration of the movie and beyond. We laughed about some of those scenes for a couple of days.  It's worth a look, especially now since it is free on Amazon Prime. Not a Prime member? Well, that is a whole 'nother review, but you're missing out.

reviewText: Growing up with my brother in the 80's, we watched any action film we could get our hands on be it hand to hand combat or martial arts - we watched all the `bigger than life' characters who could never be defeated, names like Charles Bronson, Sho Kosugi, Bruce Lee, Sylvester Stallone, Kurt Russell, Steven Seagal, Rutger Hauer, Brandon Lee, Van Damme, and so on. Eventually, when we switched the television off and the glow on its face faded away, we asked the questions only boys would think of -  in a fight between Chuck Norris and Van Damme, who would win? Etc. etc. It was fun to think about the factors involved, the risks, strengths and weaknesses, etc. There were various films made to answer this question, say a fight between Snipes and Stallone in Demolition Man or Lundgren versus Van Damme in Universal Soldier. It was our version of watching two giant Japanese monsters duke it out on the streets of Japan, and it was awesome.It's been many years since I was a boy and when I first heard about the idea of The Expendables (a huge, colossal, mega-starred spectacle) my heart did somersaults! I couldn't fathom the concept yet hoped people (agents, studios, directors, film choreographers) could all put their egos aside and actually produce an epic balls out event fit for the giant screen! Was it a success? Yes and no.While the Expendable films will never match what a boy's imagination conjures up, it did well to become reality. That, in itself is worth gold, and while shootings, stabbings, beheadings, etc. aren't everyone's cup of tea, this movie represents a genre that most males connect with and will find some comfort in - there are certain rules you don't break like banging your best friend's girl or cheating a bud out of shared riches. The buddy theme is alive and well in this film and explores the concept of being part of something special; the fact that someone has your back no matter how difficult the odds are and will stand by you is something risking your life for. To quote Kenny Rogers - sometimes you gotta fight when you're a man. But to make this point clear, these guys aren't 'good guys' in the classic vein - When you deal with revenge, it's about standing up to the injustices of the world/bullies yet these mercenaries do have a conscience - it's hard to imagine them taking on a job they know would hurt their country, for instance.The filmmakers did a great job of crafting fight scenes that highlighted each person's skills such as Jet Li's scene - too bad he doesn't stick around for too much of the film. Some of the editing is a bit rough as we're not fully given the opportunity to absorb some of the heartwarming (to call them that) moments before we're thrust into another action sequence. Still, the overall product did not make it feel like different movies were spliced together willy nilly. If I have one caveat, it's the one-liners. I'm not opposed to them - think of action sequences as the long part of an exclamation point, and a one-liner as the dot! The one line that has been sorely over-used is Schwarzenegger's line from `The Terminator' - "I'll be back." Some of the best lines (and moments) occur when the characters affirm they're not spring chickens anymore. I applaud them for poking fun at themselves, almost forgive the few crappy 1 liners.Bottom line: You should know the strength of a film like this is not going to be its story/screenplay, so if you can look past this fact and enjoy a plethora of action stunts/fights and macho attitude, you can't go wrong. I do recommend tightening the storyline for the next installment or these guys will expire before they've reached their new prime. Perhaps, they could give us a back story on how different characters met. Too bad David Carradine is 6 feet under. Damn!

reviewText: I'm a huge fan of everyone of the stars in this. The reviewers 1 staring this are taking this tongue and cheek movie waaaay to serious. The one liners and antics alone will tell you the stars themselves were not trying to project a master piece. This movie is for all the followers of favorite action hero Icons. Had they sat them all in a room watching a clock for 2 hours us diehards (No reflection on Mr. Willis lol) would have watched to the end. For those claiming it had no plot? The plot was simple and obvious. Mercenaries for hire out on a job. One of their team is murdered so they go after the guilty parties to exact revenge. The movie did not drag at all and pretty much had consistent action throughout. My only complaint is I wish it had been 2 hours longer. I guess Steven Seagal (whom I did enjoy in Above the Law, and his earlier movies) turned down a Cameo in the first Expendables one claiming he did not get along with the producer so who knows whether or not they even asked him about this one. He has been offered a role in Expendables 3. I know he had a long standing grudge with JCVD and I don't believe Stallone has him on any of his Christmas lists. Anyway enjoy the movie and watch it for what it is an action filled escape from reality with all your old movie star favorites. Wish Chuck Norris had a bigger part.

reviewText: 2010's "The Expendables" was directed by star Sylvester Stallone. It was a fun movie. For "Expendables 2", Stallone moves over(he's the star), and the director is action-veteran Simon West. More fun. "Expendables 2" did only $84 million in the U.S., but overseas ticket sales broke $300 million. Can you say No. 3? "Expendables 2" offers our noble, grizzled action stars re-united by Mr. Church(Bruce Willis) for what looks like an easy plunder-paycheck(They think). A new rookie member is gunned down right in front of the group, and an angry quest for revenge leads to a series of bloody confrontations. Tough-guy Chuck Norris shows up in the middle of the movie for a violent battle, filmed on what looks like the Warners' back lot. Chuck Norris promptly kicks everybody's butt. "Grandfather" action stars also include Arnold Schwarzenegger, Jean-Claude Van Damme, Jet Li, and Dolph Lundgren. In one scene, Schwarzenegger demands a rocket-gun being held by the big black man. The big dude says: "You better not mess with my gun, or you'll be terminated". Not missing a beat, Arnold says: "You should be so lucky..."West shoots on location in China, Hong Kong, Louisiana, and The Devetaki Cave, in Bulgaria. A light-hearted adventure, "Expendables 2" is lots of inside jokes and huff-and-puff humor. DVD extras include Blue-Ray 1080p hi-def, and DTS-HD Master Audio. The DVD is a beautiful anamorphic transfer with 5.1 Dolby Digital audio. You also get commentary with director Simon West, "Gods of War; Earth's Anti-Action Heroes" featurette, "Big Guns, Rise of the Action Film" featurette, "Assault: Real-Life Weaponry of The Expendables" featurette, "Guns for Hire" featurette, Deleted Scenes, and a Gag Reel. Our ageing band of "tough guys" all fare well. All except, perhaps, Governor Schwarzenegger. In so many scenes, his hair is fluffed-up and messy! He looks like he just got out of bed with the maid. Bang. Bang.
summary: I'm the Terminator. I'll be back...

reviewText: Let's face it.  The reason this movie gets peoples' attention is the stunt casting.  Who can resist a movie that includes Stallone, Schwartenegger, Willis, JCVD and Chuck Norris, for starters?This is definitely an updated Cannon movie from the 80s, with a bit more blood.  Sense and logic are gleefully missing from this movie in the exact same way that they were missing from the Cannon films.  While this movie has a bit of a sense of humor about itself, for example, naming the villain Villaine, it's still not quite as fun as the first one was.  And, some of the dialogue is a bit too self-referential and takes you out of the movie more than it should (for example, when a character tells Schwarzenegger that he's terminated, or words to that effect).Nonetheless, this is a decent rent and will not disappoint if you're just looking for some 80s style action with a bit of a sense of humor.
summary: Not as good as the first one but still entertaining

reviewText: The Expendables 2 is the best movie to ever put me to sleep, I think. Well, it's neck and neck with Shoot 'Em Up. And let me tell you that is saying something since a lot of movies have put me to sleep. Heck, I've probably nodded off while watching half of the movies I've saw this year. That's how much I love movies! Anyway, The Expendables 2 includes some of the best acting since I Still Know What You Did Last Summer. Sylvester Stallone proves here why he has won 7 Academy Awards. Or is that zero Academy Awards? I forget. And then there is Arnold Schwarzenegger, proving why he is still acting at the age of 80. He's good! And let's not forget Chuck Norris. He'll probably kick my butt for saying this, but he is a very handsome man. Why girls are drooling over One Direction and Justine Bieber, and not Chuck Norris is beyond me. And last and also least, is Terry Crews. What a talented black actor he is. We need more black actors like him. He's the best black actor since Chris Tucker, fer sure. As all of you know, Christmas time is upon us. So buy that special person in your life The Expendables 2 on DVD or Blue-Ray. And they too can fall asleep while watching the wonderful acting from a seasoned cast of professionals!
summary: The Best Movie That Has Ever Put Me To Sleep!

reviewText: With an action cast as magnificent as they had in this film, and obviously high budget, there is literally no excuse why every scene shouldn't kick major ass and leave you totally satisfied. Unfortunately the opposite happened-- Every scene seemed to zoom by, without any truly "cinematic" moments that are memorable. Every amazing introduction of each new character was less than lackluster, and the action wasn't anything that we haven't seen before.To have Jean Claude VanDamme as the bad guy was the coolest thing ever, and the actual movie failed to live up to that premise.As a side note, I'm also really tired of looking at CG blood explosions. It looks fake, it's always over the top, and never adds to the scene. The action giants in this film came up in an era of real pyrotechnics and squibs, and the action in those films is still better.
summary: All the elements, but poor execution

reviewText: It is not a bad idea to put a bunch of former stars together in an action film.  "Wild Bunch" is a perfect example of what can happen when it works.  Of course, when the current bunch made their careers out of glorifying their musculature and the violence of their action vehicles, it is not surprising that Jason Statham ends up as the best actor.  There is an impressive amount of failed facial cosmetic surgery on display, also.This time, the story is not bad, though the over-the-top action can be cartoonish at times.  Arnold and Bruce get more screen time, which is good, Jet Li gets less, and Chuck Norris is added -- all in all, probably a plus up.There are far better action flicks out there, and better takes on mercenaries, and each of these stars has far better films behind them.  The only reason to see this is to see them all together, for what that's worth.

reviewText: A mix of the old and the new brought on a bunch of nostalgia in this hard hitting action packed adventure! Definitely a popcorn worthy movie. I only wished that some of the other well known actors with cameo roles had more exposure. But some, well, not so much. Dolph had a terrible role as a boozer with a gun. They could have done much better with him. I guess when you have so many stars in such an action packed movie with a limited amount of time, you can't make them all the top dawg of stars, even though they could be. Stallone obviously had the major role. That's ok, though, it was still entertaining in what must have been a pretty complicated process of matching this gaggle full of stars with the various roles. If you like non stop blow-'em-up bang bang from a team of angry warriors with attitudes type of film, well this is for YOU!

reviewText: Look, the appeal of this film could not be any more obvious. But if you're somehow, for whatever psychotic reason, on the fence about seeing it, just read this paragraph and answer the question that follows:Sylvester Stallone, Chuck Norris, Jet Li, Dolph Lundgren, Jason Statham, Arnold Schwarzenegger, and Bruce Willis walk into a room with lots of things that can explode. They shoot everything in the room while cracking amusing one-liners at each other, quite a few in-jokes, and totally absurd noise and action. Jean-Claude Van Damme has a one-on-one showdown with Stallone at one point.I just described exactly what the point of this movie is in three sentences. There is nothing else that needs to be said. So, ask yourself, does this scenario appeal to you, or are you of such astoundingly poor judgment that you expected something different, much in the same way someone looking at a clear day would expect a sky colored something other than blue? If yes, great. Ignore everyone else and go see it, you'll be entertained. If not, you're so narcissistic you never would have liked this film to begin with at any point, and your ego is eating itself if you give this film a poor review on grounds it never promised in the first place.The only real problem in this film is that it's lacking in the Jet Li department. Which is really unfortunate, as he was great in the first one. Not sure what happened there, but he's not around for most of the film, which sort of sucks. So if you're here to see Li and to not see him would make you cry regardless of anything else, you should not watch this film.That's as deep as it goes. If you saw it by choice, then you expected correctly what the film was going to deliver all along. If you expected differently, short of being deceived by someone else who lied about what the COVER was about, then it's very likely that you're suffering from a severe psychosis and could benefit from treatment. You're also probably a harsh critic of the Transformers films and referred to them as "dumb action flicks" as an insult. This is an added indication that you should never review anything, ever again, because you've failed to develop the basic cognitive ability to know that people can enjoy exactly those films, and your opinion on movies may as well be a review on how provolone cheese is better than Swiss cheese. It's just as valid, really.
summary: Just like the first, this is something that doesn't even need critics.

reviewText: Overall this move was terrible -- the story, the acting, the special effects, even most of the action. THAT SAID -- Jean Claude Van Damme was really great and for me the only redeeming quality to the movie. In all of the areas where the movie fell short he was fantastic. His acting really stood out possibly because the other characters had poor dialogue and were the major participants in an overall poorly written story and dialogue. And of course his martial arts ability is always on point. Stallone -- please don't waste all of the talent you have in these movies and get a decent script writer, directer, etc., this next go around.
summary: Van Damme was great, movie was not

reviewText: "The Expendables 2" is only more of what you received with the first blockbuster film. It's definitely bigger with the introduction of new cast members such as Liam Hemsworth, Jean-Claude Van Damme, Scott Adkins, and Chuck Norris and bigger roles for Arnold Schwarzenegger and Bruce Willis, but is it better? How can a sequel and its predecessor bring together so many action stars and yet still leave so much to be desired? Somehow "The Expendables 2" tops the first movie in the sense that it leaves you with a craving for something a lot more satisfying."The Expendables 2" was originally built around the death of Tool (Mickey Rourke) and Barney and his team getting revenge because of it. Well when Rourke suddenly pulled out for another project, that load was dumped onto Billy the Kid (Liam Hemsworth). The problem is you only get to know the character for approximately ten minutes before they pull the trigger. While Billy does manage to squeeze in a story about Afghanistan, another one about getting back to his girlfriend in France, and seems to have a father-son relationship with Barney, there isn't much of an impact since his character feels like the last minute replacement that it is.The writing isn't any better this time around. Sylvester Stallone is more than likely to blame as he should probably stick to acting and directing rather than chipping in with the screenplay. These guys say the most trivial and cliché one-liners you could possibly think of. "See you later, alligator," and "Looks like somebody had a bad day," are just a few examples. The motivations of several characters are really blurred, as well. Chuck Norris enters the picture as Booker, a sniper who claims that he only works alone and is a "lone wolf." Then later shows up to help out Barney and his group again solely because, "Oh. Well, sometimes it's more fun to run with the pack." The Church (Bruce Willis) character is the worst offender. He and Barney obviously have a history together, but in the first half of the movie he's rather villainous. He throws Barney and his team right into harm's way because Barney owes Church $5 million. Church threatens Barney and basically blackmails him into this mission. But then at the end of the movie, he helps Barney and they're good buddies by the final scene.Speaking of Church, his back and forth with Trench (Arnold Schwarzenegger) is also near unbearable. Schwarzenegger already made light of his "I'm back!" catchphrase in "Terminator 3," so hearing him do it over and over again here is like beating a dead horse. Then Bruce Willis decides to say it and Arnold replies with, "Yippee ki yay," before throwing in a "Rambo" reference a moment later. It just feels so elementary.Donnie Yen was originally offered a role in this film, but turned it down. So obviously Jet Li is going to pick up the slack, right? Nope, he bows out of the film after the first ten minutes. He does manage to throw in a pretty entertaining action sequence with frying pans before he leaves though. Scott Adkins is a martial arts actor who's finally managing to pick up steam. He's more than capable of putting on a good show, but doesn't get a chance to here. You also want to see more of Van Damme, but he's dealt with rather suddenly after only delivering two of his patented jumping roundhouse kicks. Speaking of Van Damme, his character's name is Vilain. How much thought was put into that?There are very few positives with "The Expendables 2." Jason Statham has a few entertaining action sequences, but you're left wondering why one of those scenes couldn't have gone to somebody else. Dolph Lundgren's Gunnar character takes facts from his actual background like having a master's degree in engineering and even gets a bit more screen time. Aside from the opening sequence, which outdoes every explosive sequence in the first movie, explosions aren't as frequent this time around. Most of the action lies within people's heads being blown off or fistfights that never seem to last as long as you want them to."The Expendables 2" is only "bigger and better" in the sense that there are bigger additions to the cast, meatier roles for returning actors, and the amount of bullet casings collected when it's all said and done. But the downside is "The Expendables 2" is almost more of a letdown than the original movie. The dialogue is worse, character motivations are blurred, and the storyline is beyond simple. It's really only a great movie at face value because when you take a step back and realize how bad it is, you'll be left asking yourself how you gather this many well known stars in two movies and still manage to screw it up twice.In one of the special features, Sylvester Stallone talks about things being more grounded in "The Expendables 2." He says that the first film was kind of all over the place in terms of character development and it was left up in the air on whether everyone was trying to be serious or slightly lighthearted at times. Stallone mentions that having that many big stars in one picture got to him the first time around and that it's better-rounded in the sequel. Maybe it is, but it still feels like Stallone is blinded by the dense fog that is made up of all these stars coming together. Everyone is just goofy as hell all the time and Barney and Christmas act like an old married couple. There's a difference in tapping into that same cheesiness that made up nearly every strand of DNA in action films of the 80s and 90s and overdoing it. "The Expendables 2" gets way too carried away with that aspect and dives into overkill territory more often than not.Special features on the Blu-ray edition of the film include Audio Commentary with director Simon West, the 21-minute "Gods of War: Assembling Earth's Mightiest Anti-Heroes," the 25-minute "Big Guns, Bigger Heroes: The 1980s and the Rise of the Action Film," the 14-minute "On the Assault: The Real-Life Weaponry of The Expendables 2," the 24-minute "Guns For Hire: The Real Expendables," four and a half minutes of deleted scenes, and a five-minute gag reel.

reviewText: Movie critic Joe Bob Briggs set a simple rule for making the perfect sequel, "You make the same movie over again".  In that light, this was the perfect sequel.  Total "check-your-brain-at-the-door" entertainment at its best.  With brilliant use of over-the-hill/B-list action stars, funny dialog, great stunts and explosions, this movie has everything a growing boy needs except gratuitous nudity, which will probably diminish Oscar consideration.  I cannot wait until "The Expendables 3: Get Off My Lawn" becomes a reality.

reviewText: WARNING: If you did not like the first EXPENDABLES, or had no desire to see it, or do not like cliched 80's action films, you will NOT enjoy THE EXPENDABLES 2.  Just so you know.I'm not going to recite any plot points here; the plot makes absolutely no sense.  Something about uranium and a villain (named Vilain, yup), and our gang of lovable misfits gets in the way, losing  one of their own in the process (and not much surprise who gets it, either).  Stallone decides that it's payback time ("Find 'em, track 'em, kill 'em"), and the boys team up with some other major muscle-bound Neanderthals to take their vengeance.  Oh, and save the world or something.Here are the negative things about THE EXPENDABLES 2: Jason Statham's presence is smaller (though still prominent), which cuts down on the chemistry between him and Stallone that helped make the first film so enjoyable.  Same with Jet Li.  Also, Randy Couture is back; he's likable, but he doesn't have nearly as much screen presence as his comrades (though he's better here than in the first film).Now, here are the good things, or at least some of them: the film is hilarious.  Absolutely hilarious.  Chuck Norris reciting a Chuck Norris fact hilarious (and yes, Norris, as well as Arnold Schwarzenegger and Bruce Willis, have significant screen time here).  It's almost a parody, without going over-the-top in the way of AIRPLANE! and NAKED GUN.  It's as much an homage to the classic actioner as anything, right down to its two-dimensional villain: Jean-Claude Van Damme, riding an impressive (if shallow) career comeback.  Van Damme isn't mind-blowing amazing, but damn if he doesn't bring a sly sinister something to the role (as well as an impressive physicality).  Scott Adkins is a welcome addition to the villainous side, while Nan Yu provides a femme fatale presence, and Liam Hemsworth brings some surprising depth to the role of a rookie sniper.  Also, Dolph Lundgren is back with a larger role (and even a small nod to the fact he actually has a Master's in chemical engineering, if you can swallow that).  Stallone hands over directing credit to Simon West, who's proven his action worth with CON AIR and THE MECHANIC, and the change is welcome: West lets loose a little more, plays the game with more attention to wit and humor.  (Scenes between Willis and Schwarzenegger are particularly delightful.)The true draw of THE EXPENDABLES 2 is to see all of these icons in one place, doing their thing, pretty much as bad (take that how you will) as ever.  It's truly an enjoyable film; it really is.  It's intentionally funny--I've rarely seen a theater laugh so hard--and yet doesn't skimp on the action at all.  Perhaps it puts too much weight on some people not known for their acting prowess--again, Statham, who actually CAN act when required, is sorely missed in certain scenes--but that's okay, because just as soon as you begin to question how these people got into this business, Chuck Norris emerges and saves the day.  The gist: If you love class action movies, and I mean love them so much you can't help but admire even the "bad" ones, then THE EXPENDABLES 2 is a must-have for your testosterone-fueled collection.

reviewText: Let's get one thing straight.  You don't go into a movie likeThe Expendableswithout knowing what you are getting yourself into.  If you've seen the first film and enjoyed its larger-than-life salute to big 80's action stars then you know exactly what you should expect from the sequel.  It's more of the same formula: Big on star power machismo, ammunition, and one-liners and simple on plot, exposition and intelligence.  The bottom line is; you don't watch The Expendables expecting any Academy Award winning performances.  If this doesn't sound like kind of movie that you would normally enjoy watching then you came to the wrong party.The Boys are BACK: Sylvester Stallone as Barney Ross, Jason Statham as Lee Christmas, Dolph Lundgren as Gunner Jensen, Terry Crews as Hale Caesar, Randy Couture as Toll Road and Jet Li as Yin Yang while Mickey Rourke is out as Tool but the testosterone meter is still off the charts.  Liam Hemsworth joins the team as the youngest "expendable" Bill the Kid.  The Expendables have been recruited by Church to stop weapons-grade plutonium hidden in a Albanian mine during the Cold War from falling into the wrong hands and it's time to bring in the Dirtier Dozen.The muscle and all-star power are man-uped the second time around.  There's much more Arnold Schwarzenegger and Bruce Willis this time who only appeared in smaller cameo roles as Trench and Church in the first film and there's more iconic 80's action stars that the fans have been begging to see like Chuck Norris as Booker a.k.a. the "Lone Wolf" and Jean Claude Van Damme as Vilain, and what an apropos "villain" he makes.  It seems Steven Seagal is still the odd man out due to a publicized disagreement with the producer Avi Lerner, although when asked if he would be in Expendables 3 his response was "We'll see."  Rumor has it that Clint Eastwood and Harrison Ford have already been approached for the third one as well with plans to acquire Nicholas Cage and Wesley Snipes to the Expendables 3 dossier.Expendables 2 is a blast if you can appreciate it for what it is; it's the guiltiest kind of guilty pleasure and it makes no apologies for being what it is.  The first one feels almost like a dress rehearsal but the sequel is bigger and a lot more fun.  There are hilarious one-liners and bad puns aplenty and the chemistry between these legendary screen icons takes badassery to a whole new cinematic level.  The epic showdown between "The Italian Stallion" Stallone and the "Muscles From Brussels" Van Damme makes it worth the price of admission alone.Bring on Expendables 3!  Yippee ki yay!

reviewText: This movie stretches "suspension of disbelief" credibility way too far. There were battle scenes where our heroes are about to be eliminated by the armies of bad guys, when all of a sudden a hero who had been quickly introduced earlier comes form out of the blue to save the day. The heroes always outrun the machine gun bullets, while the bad guys die like lemmings. A high point of the film are the inside jokes, and fun the stars poke at each other. The film is enjoyable to watch, but you have to disregard logic too often.

reviewText: "The Expendables 2" resurrects every surviving action star from the 1980's and dumps them into a formula action movie with a tissue paper thin plot and bucketloads of one-liners, and guess what?  It's not bad.  "The Expendables 2" is entertaining, rolls with its own punches, and stacks one outrageous action scene after another on the audience, helped along by an unending parade of cameos by Jet Li, Chuck Norris, Arnold Schwarzenagger, Bruce, Willis, and Jean-Claude Vandamme, among others.The exotic opening sequence has a group of aging mercenaries known as the Expendables rescuing a Chinese millionaire from a rebel camp in Nepal.  Afterwards, they celebrate, led by crew boss Barney Ross (Slyvester Stallone).  Their next mission is a CIA tasking to retrieve a mysterious package, accompanied by a female minder named Maggie.  The retrieval goes badly, a member of Barney's crew gets killed, and the crew decides to seek revenge.  The final confrontation with a group of nasty mercenaries in a remote airport is part action thriller and part a collection of sight gags, as stars and former stars wander in and out of frame.The violence is practically continuous but fortunately manages to be mostly over the top, along with most of the acting.  "The Expendables 2" is a fun way to spend a couple of hours, and recommended for that.  It helps if you are a fan of older action movies; more of the jokes will make sense.

reviewText: The action film has a curious history.  Granted, studios didn't begin pumping them out in the `80's, but, to a large part, they experienced a significant retooling in that bygone era.  Mostly, this renaissance was fueled by the big budget star - think Sylvester Stallone, Jean-Claude Van Damme, and Arnold Schwarzenegger - coming aboard a particular action vehicle and asking for the part to be customized to what his fans had come to expect.  In many cases, this only served to strengthen the picture, as the hero would be put through his paces in such a manner that maximized entertainment value.  However, the action picture kinda/sorta suffered in the long run because too many pictures plucked from the same wellspring of inspiration has the cumulative (over time) of thinning out the premises.  Pictures started to resemble one another, and - even worse - catch phrases became horribly predictable with each passing 90-minute flick.  Still, while the formula worked, it was a doozy, so who can blame Stallone and his cohorts for leaping back into the ring for another go-round?(NOTE: the following review will contain minor spoilers necessary for the discussion of plot and characters.  If you prefer your reviews largely spoiler-free, then feel free to skip down to the last two paragraphs for my final assessment.  If you're okay with some basic explanations and hints of things to come, then read on.)Church (played by Bruce Willis) pulls the Expendables back into action in order to settle a lingering old score with Barney Ross (Sylvester Stallone).  However, he insists that the team incorporate Maggie (Nan Yu) as a vault specialist to recover a secret map that conceals weapons' grade Plutonium.  However, Vilain (Jean-Claude Van Damme) has other plans for the materials, and, when he kills the youngest member of the Expendables crew (Liam Hemsworth in a brief appearance), the mission becomes a race against time to save the world from a lunatic with aspirations of a nuclear weapon.Now, for the record, let me just clarify right away that the best thing about EXPENDABLES 2 is the fact that action fans are finally treated to some quality screen time shared by three film legends: Stallone, Schwarzenegger, and Willis.  They've long been rumored to be friends off-screen, and there's nothing - NOTHING - that can ever replace seeing them together, working together, shooting guns together (at the bad guys), and dispensing their own respective brands of justice.  It's that fuel that makes this franchise burn, and burn brightly.  Add Jason Statham to the mix, and you should have pure cinema perfection, right?Well ...Like the action picture fell at the wayside with some measure of predictability in the late 80's and early 90's, EXPENDABLES 2 suffers from that same mushy story logic and a desire on the part of all involved to have a moment.  Most of the jokes and one-liners work just fine - swimmingly, in fact - but there are a few that could've been easily trimmed.  Unlike the first go-round, this second installment feels a bit bloated, and that's probably because every action star and their kitchen sinks were chucked in here.  As a consequence, some of it ends up being more than a bit schlocky ... and that's never a good thing.For example, Chuck Norris joins the film as Booker, an almost infamous professional of legendary status.  I won't spoil it for viewers, but, suffice it to say, his addition here comes off more cartoonish than it does anything else.  There's nothing wrong with a kind of invulnerability (we expect THAT of our action heroes) ... but an almost magical, mystical ability to appear in the middle of a firefight when no one called?  That's over-the-top ... and, speaking of over-the-top, Stallone made an action / family film called OVER THE TOP, and I'm surprised that didn't serve as a joke here.Some of the material grows tired in this second go-round, but, as I hear a third script is being fleshed out at present, let's hope the movie gods don't make the same errors next time.  It's precisely this kind of thinking that brought the traditional action flicks of the 80's and 90's crashing to a halt at the cineplexes.  Let's keep an eye on our history, Sly, and let's not have that happen again.THE EXPENDABLES 2 is produced by Millennium Films and Nu Images Films.  DVD distribution is being handled through Lionsgate.  As for the technical specs ... you're kidding, right?  This is a Sylvester Stallone picture, and good ol' Sly knows more than a thing or two about high quality technical specs.  It looks and sounds amazing, just as it should.  Likewise, Sly knows what his fans expect, so he chocks the disc full of extras, including an audio commentary with director Simon West, deleted scenes, a gag reel, and some explosive behind-the-scenes shorts focusing in on the stars, their weapons, and even a respectable history looking back at the rise of the action film ... but very little about the fall of it as a genre.  Simply put: there's everything here an action fan could want and more.  Enjoy it while it's hot!RECOMMENDED mostly for fans of action cinema, though some will no doubt be a bit disappointed in this follow-up as I was.  After an exceptional opening action sequence to put the motion picture in high gear, THE EXPENDABLES 2 settles in way too comfortably into much of the same goofy, loopy territory that helped kill the big budget action picture about two decades ago.  It ain't all bad - with the kind of star power behind this there's always a good shot coming - it's just that this one succumbs to predictability much sooner than its predecessor did.  With Norris, Van Damme, Willis, and Schwarzenegger coming aboard with more screen time, I would've hoped for more.  While THE EXPENDABLES was two steps forward, part 2 was two steps back.In the interests of fairness, I'm pleased to disclose that the fine folks at Lionsgate provided me with a DVD screener copy of THE EXPENDABLES 2 by request for the expressed purposes of completing this review.
summary: 2 and  Stars: EXPENDABLES 2 Expands On Franchise, But Not In A Good Way

reviewText: I have to admit, I am concerned with how the youth of our country are affected by the violence and easy killing in games and movies these days. It is exciting to see these action stars all working together and seemingly having fun doing so. The realism of most of the action scenes never enters the realm of plausability. Therefore, this movie becomes total entertainment!

reviewText: The Good: An amazing opening action sequence instantly ropes you into the movie.  Jean-Claude Van Damme is the best thing about this movie, he's funny and makes an excellent villain (because he also comes across as menacing).  This movie is funnier than the first one, the chemistry has built up more between Stallone and Statham.  Their bickering will have you laughing.  The dialogue is also an improvement from the first one, granted, it's not going to win for best screenplay, but it helps move things along.  Chris Hemsworth provides the best acting in the movie (like Mickey Rourke in the first one).  He almost seems out of place in this movie because his acting is too good.  Seeing all the biggest action stars of the 80's blow apart an airport together (with civilians still in the line of fire) is an action fan's dream.  oh, and Chuck Norris of course.The Bad:  This movie isn't as well-paced as the first one.  There is a gap where the movie sort of stagnates and attempts to develop its characters with mediocre dialogue.  There are some chuckles during this time, but you'd rather just see stuff blow up and everyone yelling like maniacs.  This movie puts its best foot forward with that opening action sequence, the rest of the movie never matches up to those first 10-15 minutes.  I felt they should have given Van-Damme a bit more in the last fight scene with Sly.  The spin kick ruled, but he should have bounced Sly's head off a wall a couple of times to make the fight more even. Arnold Schwarzenegger, I love Arnold, but he sucked in this movie.  'I'm back' 'He'll be back' 'Everyone is back' enough.  Usually, his awful jokes are funny, but here, their just regular awful.The Deal: This movie is exactly what you think it is and Sly knows it.  It's very tongue-in-cheek where these guys can poke fun at themselves.  If you are an action fan you will catch some of the inside stuff going on here (Knock,Knock written on the tank in the beginning, a reference to one of Arnold's lines from Predator).  This movie delivers from an action standpoint, which is the only standpoint it has to deliver.  This is a slightly better movie than the first one in part because there is some semblance of a plot (Van Damme stealing plutonium to sell to a buyer).  Good enough for me. Let's blow s**t up!!!

reviewText: The Expendables are back with new members as they reunite to take on a simple job. The task looks easy for this mission, but things go wrong, and one of their own is viciously killed. The group venture out to seek revenge in hostile territory, against all odds. The crew enter into a world of destruction, wreaking havoc and turmoil as they shut-down an unexpected threat. Their mission is not complete, until justice is served against the villain who murdered their brother. Acting Performance of: Sylvester Stallone, Jason Statham, Jet Li, Arnold Schwartzenegger, and Bruce Willis is Superb. The drama is intense throughout, and this movie is as much of a SLAM-BANG Action Thriller as 'THE ROCK' is with Nicolas Cage. There are edge-of-your-seat thrills, and entertaining from start to finish. Highly Recommended to all action and thriller lovers!

reviewText: Yee-hah! The Preparation H will flow tonight, and the Salonpas! THE EXPENDABLES 2, even more than the first one, is a reunion of sorts for them 1980s action film heroes. It's unabashedly cheesy. It's unapologetically nostalgic. It evokes the zeitgeist of an era three decades gone. Don't overthink the movie. Take it for what it is, as a last hurrah for most of the cast.The plot, for what it's worth: Barney Ross (Stallone), chief dog of an elite merc team, owes the CIA officer, Mr. Church (Willis), a favor, and so off goes his team to retrieve a computer containing blue prints that pinpoint the location of nearly five tons of weapons-grade plutonium. Except the team botches the job, one penalty of which is the cost of a team member's life. Now regard Stallone, veins popping, very much vengeance-minded and so cheesed he's now even more at odds with his archnemesis, enunciation. When asked by his first lieutenant, Lee Christmas (Statham), "What's the plan?" I think he says "Track him. Find him. Kill him."My quick flurries: I guess Jean-Claude Van Damme's career is in the grip of a mini-revival. I really likedJCVD, in which he played a more down-and-out version of himself. Here, he's very effective and menacing as the film's big bad. Of course, we're treated to his signature helicopter kick. But he needed to guard himself against Sly in their climactic showdown, because Sly has a secret weapon. At any given moment those marbles in his mouth could serve as deadly projectiles.This sequel boasts more wrinkles than the set of Golden Girls, more popped-out veins than in a Rolling Stones hotel suite. Willis and Schwarzenegger return with expanded roles, and there's a really awkward, corny moment in which they trade catch phrases. Gratifyingly, Chuck Norris surfaces to save Sly and company's bacons. At his age, Chuck is better off shooting heavy artillery than dropkicking a dude. Never one to miss dropping a reference, Sly greets Chuck's timely entrance with "You the one people call the Lone Wolf?" Did you groan, too?Jet Li makes use of the little time he's in this film - he literally drops out early on - by showcasing his wushu skills in one electrifying segment. This is very cool as I was disappointed that, in the first film, he was mostly firing weapons. However, it's Jason Statham who shines brightest in the action sequences. What that man can do with a knife...The acting? It's okay. No one bit their tongue or anything. Liam Hemsworth, as the team's newest and youngest sniper recruit, acquits himself surprisingly well with the dramatics. Sly and Statham again demonstrate their nice buddy chemistry. But let's not kid ourselves. We're here because we're not only action junkies, we've a soft spot for retro action films. The plot is by-the-numbers, but you couldn't tell me that while I was taking in all the explody stuff and these geriatric heroes wallowing in it. This is such a fun and wild ride! This cast reminds me a bit of the Oceans 11 cast in terms of big name pedigree, except, y'know, this bunch is more wrinkly and more in need of a spot in the gym and also more likely to bed Sally Fields or Nichelle Nichols. I think there'll be a third film. My fingers are crossed for trigger-happy spots for Eastwood, Seagal, Chan, and Gibson. And maybe Carl Weathers, wherever he is.The DVD's bodacious bonus stuff:- Audio Commentary with director Simon West- "Gods of War: Assembling Earth's Mightiest Antiheroes" - just a lot of marveling at the fact that they were able to get all these big name stars together (00:21:16 minutes)- "Big Guns, Bigger Heroes: The 1980s and the Rise of the Action Film" - examining the 1980s action film hero as a mirror of President Reagan and tracking the evolution of the action film from Stallone to Willis (00:24:57)- "On the Assault: The Real-Life Weaponry of THE EXPENDABLES" - Randy Couture hosts a tour of the Gun Store in Las Vegas and shoots on the gun range with weapons that were used in the film (the FN Scar L, Sly's M1911 and Colt Single Action, Crew's Benelli M4, Van Damme's Steyr Aug A3, etc) (00:13:34)- "Guns for hire: The Real Expendables" - Real-life private security firms like Trojan Securities International and Ronin Worldwide get some pub (00:24:17)- 5 Deleted Scenes, including more of Crews and Couture in action (totaling 00:04:38)- Gag Reel (00:05:08)

reviewText: I went and saw this with my dad shortly after it hit the theater and we loved it!  I very much enjoyed the first Expendables movie, but I would have to say that I enjoyed this one even a little bit better.  I was a bit sad to see Jet Li leave the group, but oh well...it was still an awesome movie!  Haha, and Chuck Norris!  Very cool to see him back in action again!  He even cracks one of his own Chuck Norris jokes in the movie!  LoL!Here's what it boils down to:  If you're seeking a good solid plot in a movie, this movie may not exactly have what you're looking for...much like the first one.  However, if you're looking for a heavy hitting action extravaganza with lots of of shooting and explosions, with a bit of good humor thrown in, then look no further!  These movies are for the die hard action fans, and if you're one of those types, then you'll simply love this movie!In closing, I do have to say that I was not really a big fan of the Asian chick they threw into the movie...I feel the movie would have faired just fine without her.  At the very least, they could have found someone better for the role I think, because I'm sorry to say, the one they added into it just wasn't that great of an actress I felt.  That's just my own personal opinion though.  However, her roles aren't very big in it and it's not enough of a matter to really take away from the enjoyment of this movie for me.  Totally awesome!

reviewText: Well, I saw this at the movies a couple of days ago and I have to admit I was really entertained.  The all star cast is what drew me to it.  I wasn't disappointed at all. Enjoy!.....  I did.

reviewText: The Expendables was an enjoyable ride, for what it was, Stallone certainly knows how to go after action, there's no doubt about it, it's what he does. reviewText: When Sylvester Stallone dreamt up the original EXPENDABLES film, it was designed to be a throwback to the cheesy 80's shoot-'em-up spectacles that were low on plot and character and high on action and adrenaline and combine many of cinema's greatest (or at least somewhat famous) action stars in one film, and it succeeded in some ways and failed in others. The biggest problem that I had with the original is that there were too many patented Stallone-As-Screenwriter moments when he tried to make the film more serious than it EVER needed to be. But when the action was on, it was really glorious to watch all of the over-the-top silliness explode like a Wile E. Coyote cartoon on crank. Fortunately we're treated to much more of that silliness and much less of the seriousness in the Simon West (CON AIR, LARA CROFT: TOMB RAIDER) directed EXPENDABLES 2.As the film opens with a terrific opening set piece of an assault on a fortified bunker, we are reintroduced to our team of Expendables: Barney (Stallone, not losing a step), Lee Christmas (Jason Statham, he of the mighty chin and eternal 5-O'Clock-Shadow), Gunnar (Dolph Lundgren, who's gone from potential villain to one of the good guys again), Yin Yang (Jet Li, still short), Caesar (Terry Crews and his loud auto-shotgun), Toll Road (Randy Couture... who's barely there), and the new kid on the block, Billy (Liam Hemsworth). The whole opening sequence is an orgy of heads and limbs popping off, kung-fu butt-kicking, geysers of digital blood, and big BIG explosions. It also reveals another bit player with a much larger role in this film, and that is the character of Trench, played by none other than the former Governator himself, looking to get back into film in a big (and fun) way. After a brief interlude, Yin Yang departs the film for... really no particular reason, and they're down a man. When they arrive home, Barney in confronted by the mysterious Company man Mr. Church (played with much more relish this time around by Bruce Willis), who orders his merry band to go and intercept a "package" that's been lost in a plane crash in a faraway land. Church also insists that one of his people, Maggie (the lovely and lethal Nan Yu, whose only other "major" Hollywood role was in SPEED RACER), goes along for the ride in order to secure the package. Before you can say "Time for the big villain entrance", it's time for the big villain entrance, and that is in the personage of Vilain (yes, that's his character's name) as portrayed by Jean-Claude Van Damme (clearly having a good time playing the bad guy). Vilain and his crew rather shockingly kill one member of the team, and that leads our Expendables on a path to vengeance. Vilain leads a vicious group of mercenaries and other cut-throat types whose current objective is to steal five tons of old Soviet weapons-grade Plutonium and sell it to the highest bidders. Church, Trench and another player who appears on the board named Booker (Chuck Norris, playing up his "Lone Wolf" image... get it? "Lone Wolf"?) all come together to take down Vilain and his operation and his seeminlgly endless parade of cannon fodder.Basically everything that was good about the first film is better here. West has a much better and more dynamic style than Stallone does when it comes to having some flair about the action sequences. The film also knows when to lay off the more serious moments to create more forward momentum. Some may find this to be a disservice to the character, but believe me, if this film had gotten bogged down in this death and the reflection/meditation on life and death that the first film had, it would have done the film a greater disservice. The whole cast, particularly the old-timers, seem to be having a really good time here, even if some of them have less to do because of the inclusion of Schwarzenegger, Willis and Norris getting in on the action. The second act does plod on a little, but the film, coming in at a brisk 103 minute run-time, doesn't allow the film to plod for very long.The other thing that is much more evident in this film is its self-awareness. This film, unlike the first film, is VERY aware that it takes place in "Action Movie/Video Game Land", as opposed to a semi-realistic setting. Just look at the opening sequence; the good guys fire their weapons with unfailing accuracy as they travel at fifty miles per hour while the throngs of bad guys couldn't hit the broad side of a barn. The sea-plane used in the first film has been retrofitted into an airborne tank. In the second act, one man is able to take down a few dozen bad guys AND a tank in a matter of about seven seconds. By the third act, you have our heroes crashing planes into the ground with no real consequences, drilling machines coming out of nowhere, and people RIPPING THE DOORS OFF CARS. This same idea also applies to the character motivations and dialogue: Vilain is evil because he's the villain and he knows it (It's in his name, for God's sakes), and even has the line "No loose ends" at one point. The good guys are super-quipping machines. Willis and Schwarzenegger share a scene where they throw each other's movie catch-phrases in their faces. This film has abandoned all pretense of reality and that makes it work SO much better than the first film. It's also a real thrill for those of us action fans who were coming of age in the 80's to see Sly, Bruce, Ahnuld, and Chuck killing dozens of bad guys together. The only notable absence from the first film is that of Mickey Rourke, who, admittedly wasn't much of an action star anyway, unless you want to count HARLEY DAVIDSON AND THE MARLBORO MAN or the Van Damme/Dennis Rodman action film DOUBLE TEAM. I think those films are better off forgotten, though, don't you?The best sequels are the ones that learn from the mistakes of the previous films and improve on what made the original entertaining in the first place, and THE EXPENDABLES 2 absolutely does all of that and ends up being one of the more entertaining, if least substantial, films of the summer.4/5 Stars.

reviewText: I am an optimist and I always hope things in which I choose to invest my limited time exceed my expectations.  Infrequently, I am rewarded for diving into something with the remotest promise, but this movie wasn't one of them.  I expected the movie to be predictable...and wasn't disappointed in that respect, but the actors and performances were so tired the movie lost my attention occasionally.  The dialogue had some humorous quips of the type you expect from the plot and the characters and that was "comforting", but the long-promised and awaited confrontation between good and evil at the end of the movie could not penetrate the low-energy bored complexion the movie had assumed by the time it arrived.  When it was done, the feeling I was left with was, "What else did you expect?".  Even after stating all that, I would probably spend another 2 hours or so on Expendables 3 if one was released.
summary: More Caffeine for the Plot...and the Actors!

reviewText: Expendables 2 played off the strengths of the first, while also expanding on it's weaknesses as well. Instead of mere cameos, Bruce Willis and Arnold Schwarzenegger play have acting roles and of course, none other than CHUCK NORRIS comes in! The tongue in cheek references to past hit movies from each of the leading actors is priceless, down to the subtle commentary about Dolph Lundgren's characters intelligence. Unlike before, Jet Li shows off his hand to hand fighting skills as does Jason Statham, though Jet Li's time on screen is far too limited for my taste. It even leaves room to pass the baton to up and coming action stars (younger Helmsworth and Scott Adkins). There is little adherence to a plot, but that serves this particular movie well. It doesn't pretend to be an Oscar, rather, it allows itself to live up to it's true purpose- a tribute, an homage to the high intensity action stars from the 80's and 90's. One of my favorite movies of all time!Bottom line if you loved the first you will love this one as it dose deliver.

reviewText: It's got the basic special features with director commentary if you into that and digital copy is readily accessible online but for those who may not be based in the US ... you CANNOT access nor download your digital copy though you have paid for it.As for the movie, if you liked The Expendables then you're in for a treat because part 2 is all that and more! I hate selling out a movie ... like those trailers that after watching it you feel as if you just watched the entire movie in 5 minutes ... but there are some good surprises in this film. The story line is definitely stronger and more in depth than the first (good improvement) but they also cut the story for the sake of senseless action. Not a bad trade off in my opinion.Of course with an all action star line up you may be wondering about the quality of acting but it's all good, no disappointments at all but then most of my favorite 80s and 90s stars are in there so possible biased and boy do they all look old!So if you don't like movie spoilers, don't read on ...Stallone and Statham have a real good connection and make a good team, though I think there is less emphasis on Statham's character and more on Stallone. Jet Li got more a guest appearance at the start but hopefully he'll be back if there's another installment because he was missed.Finally a real movie that starred Willis, Arnold (don't pretend to spell his surname) and Stallone with a compliment of other good action stars. Yes there are a few tacky statements about each other that could have been left out but there's also some good humor in it. Van Damme played a fantastic bad guy; I mean have you seen his productions in the last 10 years? Less than entertaining but he really did a good job here. But the best and most ridiculous thing is Chuck Norris who mysteriously appears in the middle of the movie whne you need him most ... the true Lone Wolf.Hats off to a great sequel.
summary: Hats off to a great sequel ...

reviewText: Imagine walking into a nursing home and both residents and nurses are strapped to the nines engaged in some serious ass kicking altercations. One group of residents and nurses, led by an old guy with a funky French accent, is leading the charge to acquire all of the home's oxygen tanks to sell them to the nursing home across town for an astronomical price. Then there's the other group of residents and nurses, are led by an old guy with a drunken slur, and they are making every effort to stop the diabolical transaction from coming to a head. Now picture two random old guys who show up every now and then, bantering at each other and using the other's "tag lines" from 60 years ago, when they were 22.Now imagine that you stopped imagining the nursing home conflict and you actually went and watched The Expendables 2. I guarantee you that by the end of the film, you'll feel like you acquired dementia because you'll start to wonder if you forgot to take your medication for Monday, Tuesday, and Wednesday when you realize that not even you can duck and dodge around a staged scene, like Stallone, without the pain of arthritis and the risk of shattering your pelvis.Individually, all of these actors rock their own films. But for some reason when they're lumped all together into a single movie, it's seriously like watching an altercation at a nursing home.

reviewText: The Expendables 2 is a sequel to the 2010 feature film, and I'm happy to say that it's better than the first movie. Like the first film, The Expendables 2 pays tribute to action films of the 1980s and early 1990s, but this time it's not directed by Sylvester Stallone, but rather Simon West, and the shaky camera from the first film is gone, which is a plus.The group of elite mercenaries are sent out to retrieve an item from a safe in an airplane that was shot down in Albania. Church (Bruce Willis) has Maggie Chan (Yu Nan) join the mercenaries because she's a technical expert, and is able to crack the safe once the team finds it. The mercenaries get ambushed by an arms dealer, Jean Vilain (Jean-Claude Van Damme), who wants the item the team retrieved from the safe. The team surrenders the item, but Jean Vilain kills one of their teammates. The team must retrieve the item from the safe while avenging their fallen comrade's death.The Expendables 2 has a great cast which includes: Sylvester Stallone, Jason Statham, Jet Li, Dolph Lundgren, Chuck Norris, Bruce Willis, Randy Couture, Terry Crews, Liam Hemsworth, Jean-Claude Van Damme, Arnold Schwarzenegger, and Nan Yu. Unlike the first film, I found that the Expendables 2 shared more camera time with the actors, although Jet Li's camera time got cut into half from the first, and Jet Li fans will be highly disappointed.This time around, the jokes don't fall flat, the action scenes are better staged, the script is better written, and the plot is more enjoyable. The Expendables 2 isn't a great movie, but it does a better job at capturing a good 80/90's action flick. The action is plenty, the plot is still thin, but I definitely enjoyed this better than the first movie, as did my wife. Overall, if you like action films, you'll be satisfied. If you want to see the movie because of the actors, you'll be more satisfied this time around. The Expendables 2 gets a highly recommended 'rent.'
summary: Recently watched movie review: The Expendables 2 (2012)

reviewText: When I first heard of The Expendables film back in 2009 I was excited, and what man who grew up in the 1980's and 1990's. Sylvester Stallone was making a hall of fame and all-star action film that brought together himself along with Dolph Lundgren, Jet Li, Jason Statham, Stone Cold Steve Austin, and Gary Daniels to name a few. You had action stars from the 1980's, 1990's and 2000's all in the same film. It seemed like a good and fun idea and I thought it would be a great action film. I went to see it when it first came out and leaving the theater I was disappointed. It was at best an action film, and it suffered at The Avengers suffered from. It's a great concept to bring together larger than life action or superheroes, but once you get by the excitement of seeing all your favorite action stars or superheroes in the same film you begin to see the flaw that are plainly there to see. The Avengers had them, but nowhere near as bad as The Expendables. For that reason I when I heard that there was going to be a sequel I wasn't excited. I was interested and paid attention to the news about the film, but I wasn't going to pay ten dollars or more for what I thought was going to be an average action film at best, and after seeing The Expendables 2 recently I was right not to waste my money.The Expendables 2 is much worse than the original. In fact after I watched the film and gave it time the worse my opinion of the film grew. The Expendables overall plot is about them trying to stop a cache of plutonium which Jean Claude Van-Damn is after. Yes I'm not even going to use their character names, because they aren't any characters in this film. I mean who cares about this men whether they live or die, or if you can understand them. Take the first opening action scene I couldn't understand a word they anyone was saying except the curse words, and maybe that's all that they were saying which also led to about a fourth of dialogue to be completely unrecognizable. Next they brought characters in and out of the film for real no reason except to show off as many action stars as possible while being detrimental to the film. For example Jet Li is a great action star, but they got rid of him with in the first ten minutes and introduced us Liam Hemsworth who I believe played Billy a sniper. On a side note Liam really needs to ask his brother Chris for some help with roles. I know he'll get more time in the sequel, but he had like two lines in The Hunger Games and he's just a throw away character that Stallone and the director Simon West try to make us care about. I mean they introduce him he shows off his ability as a sniper, talks about leaving to be with his girlfriend even though they don't we have no connection to the character or care what happens to him, and then he's killed off about ten to fifteen minutes after Li disappears from the film. Oh yes I forgot in the beginning of the film Stallone and his team go rescue some billionaire and end rescuing Arnold Schwarzenegger who is there for some convenient reason to say some funny dialogue and then vanishes. I know I know defenders of this film will say the action films are generally ridiculous and over the top, but The Expendables 2 is laughably ridiculous only in bad way. Most and good action films have a coherent plot and the viewer actually comes to care about the main character or character. The Expendables has turned into the action version of the Ocean films which is basically the same premise bringing together great actors, but studios, directors and even the stars need to realize that bringing together these stars may mean big bucks, but it doesn't mean the film will actually be good. This is turning into a long paragraph. I would talk about the acting, but honestly there is no good acting in this film. During the film Chuck Norris miraculously shows up for some convoluted and convenient reason and saves Stallone's team and then gives some reason about being a lone wolf and disappears again. There really isn't any reason to care about the story or the characters. To be honest each of these action stars films are better than The Expendables 2.All right enough about the bad plot, non-existent characters or the ridiculous dialogue, and let's move on to the action, which is supposed to be the bread and butter of this growing franchise. I have seen a lot of good action films recently in Skyfall, El Gringo, Dredd and Looper. I know I know again defenders of this film will say action films are supposed to be over the top. Yes if it makes sense like for example the Die Hard films. Sure there was some unbelievable action scenes, but they weren't outrageously over the top like in The Expendables films. Directors and actors should know sometimes less is better than more over the top action. Having so many action stars in the film makes the scenes unmemorable and unremarkable. Stallone has plane with a cannon in its nose and he crashes it into a mine, so what and who cares. They climax is in an airport with a hundred unknown or indefinable bad guys while the good guys just shoot their guns and spout some ridiculous dialogue. The action and fight scenes have no meaning and aren't entertaining in anyway.On paper the idea of the Ocean and The Expendables films is a good idea, but as it's put together things quickly fall apart with too many characters to care about, an average to bad plot, bad dialogue and average to bad action or drama, and that is what both of these franchised suffered from and to a lesser extend The Avengers. Like I said once you get over the excitement of seeing all these famous actors, action stars or superheroes together you see the flaws in the film. Overall The Expendables 2 is a bad action film which has limited value in seeing all these action stars together and a few funny lines.

reviewText: Here I am with my review of expendables 2 this isn't going to be an in depth review just 1st viewing thoughts. I feel it's a good sequel I don't know if it's good as 1st movie thought I have seen that movie a few times & I love it. Now I saw the teaser late last year & it didn't interest me the guy they got to direct Simon West hasn't had a good track record the past 10 years. I heard they made it PG 13 from the start. I had my concern's about it. Stallone not directing & such. I saw the newer trailers & it got me excited I was going to see it anyway being a big fan of the 1st. I saw it & I enjoyed it. I do feel Stallone ghost directed it & Simon West did what he was told. All of the characters return Slyvester Stallone as Barney Ross, Jason Statham as Lee Christmas, Dolph Lundgren as Gunner Jenson, Terry Crews as Hale Ceaser, Randy Couture as Toll Road, Arnold Schwarzenegger as Trench, Bruce Willis as Mr Chruch, Chuck Norris as Booker, Jean Cluade Van Damme as Jean Villain, Scott Atkins as Hector, Nan Yu as ,Maggie, Liam Hemsworth as as Billy The Kid & Jet Li as Yin Yang, I'm not doing a huge retrospective with the plot I'll do a big in depth review when I get this movie on DVD or Blu Ray. Just a quick run down is Mr Church has Barney Ross & his team go to Albania to retrive a device from a safe from a plane that crashed you're introduced to this girl named Maggie that can crack the code cause the safe changes comnbinations every 127 seconds. Now originally it was suppose to be Mickey Rourke that was killed but he didn't return as Tool Box so if you've seen this movie you know which Merc is killed. The Merc's are confronted by Jean Villain who kills 1 of The Merc's not telling he takes the device they got from the safe that has blue prints to an abandoned mine that has tons of Plutonium from The Cold War. This movie is plentiful in action. I'm glad they didn't go with the shakey cam. There is CGI & if you don't kow I hate CGI & prefer practical effects. I do think they should've went with practical from the start. But as long as I have fun have characters that I like I really don't get on CGI as much. I can tell that they went for an PG 13 from the start & decided to add gore to get a R rating. But I enjoyed myself this past Friday as I said I'll go more in depth when I get it on Blu Ray. I liked the referances to Terminator, Rambo & the tiny little nod to Cobra. There were some really good fights in here with Stallone & Van Damme. Jason Stahman & Scott Atkins. Simon West did a good job listening to Stallone. Slyvester Stallone did a great job again. Jason Statham did fine. Dolph Lundgren did good. Terry Crews was ok. Randy Couture did ok. Scott Atkins I feel was there to get a younger demographic & I could of done without him. Nan Yu was did a very good job. Bruce Willis was good. Arnold Schwarzenegger was very good. Chuck Norris didn't get whole lot of screen time but he did a good job. No pun intended Jet Li had a really small role but he did fine. Jean Claude Van Damme was pretty good he did he wasn't playing it like he was a zombie like he did in Universal Soldier Regeneration or how he will in Day Of Reckoning or how he did in Assassination Games. Scott Atkins was pretty good. As I said with the 1st Expendables don't go in expecting an Oscar Contender & enjoy.

reviewText: An action flick for the ADD. There is no real story here, just a bunch of explosions. Although it is nice to see our old favorite action heroes, plastic surgery, or in some cases a rough life (evidently), have made some of them look inhuman. The creepiest are Dolph (who does indeed look like Frankenstein's Monster), JCVD (whose eyes, post surgery, resemble either the Creature from the Black Lagoon or Fu Man Chu), and Stallone (who's eerie white plastic face hovers above a non-matching body). At one point I had to look away because they were stroking each other so much with their homage's and punchlines, I thought they were going to blow each other (not up).Stallone's muscles look so tensed/tight that he appears ready to explode, like in the ending of some weird sci-fi movie. There is a particular cut, in the opening slaughter fest, where Stallone and Stratham go from riding in a jeep on the ground to suddenly piloting a plane...? I am sure this movie, which appears to have been written as it was being filmed (there is no real story) will appease many fans of mindless violence, but reaches a level of violence that is almost a parody.
