reviewText: Here I am with a review for The Expendables 2 which I saw in the theater in The Summer of 2012 while I prefer the 1st movie this sequel comes very close & it rocks. I can see why people like this movie over the 1st Expendables but for whatever reason I like the 1st more. There isn't much wrong in fact this movie is awesome if you told me like 15 or 20 years ago that their would be a movie where Sylvester Stallone, Arnold Schwarzenegger, Bruce Willis & Chuck Norris would star in it I'd think you were lying. When I saw the 1st Expendables you had Arnold Schwarzenegger & Bruce Willis in cameos I hoped that Stallone would give them more to do. While Stallone didn't direct this movie he did write the script & hopefully have some control. I will admit I had my concern's when I heard this movie would bePG 13 cause the 1st Expendables was R also I was concerned how certain guys were going to be used. I had read that this movie was shot PG 13 from the get go I believe that cause it looked like CGI gore was added. But getting to the movie it was made on $100 million & made $312 million directed by Simon West he directed Con Air, The General's Daughter, Tomb Raider & The When A Stranger Call remake which blows. The cast all return except for Mickey Rourke. Sylvester Stallone as Barney Ross, Jason Statham as Lee Christmas, Dolph Lundgren as Gunner Jensen, Terry Crews as Hale Caesar, Randy Couture as Toll Road, Arnold Schwarzenegger as Trench Mauser, Bruce Willis as Mr Church & Jet Li as Yin Yang. You have some newer cast members Jean Claude Van Damme as Jean Vilain, Chuck Norris as Booker, Scott Adkins as Hector, Liam Hemsworth as Billy The Kid & Yu Nan as Maggie. The movie starts off in Nepal where The Expendables have to go rescue a hostage who turns out to be Trench Mauser. You open up to a great action scene with the team just mowing down enemy soldiers. There is also this really cool fight scene with Jet Li in The kitchen using kitchen items on these enemy soldiers. When  they find Trench he says that this is embarrassing. Trench asks for a weapon he takes Hale Caesar's AA 12 Shotgun he says that if he doesn't get it back his a  *  * is terminated. Arnold Schwarzenegger responds "In your dreams." Your introduced to Billy The Kid who is a Sniper he kills some of the enemy troops when the team is surrounded. Plus you get a really entertaining chase scene in the water where the team is trying to get aboard the plane. You have the team at the bar having a good time Lee is still together with Lacy & it was nice that they followed that up to show that sub plot mattered. You have Billy tell Barney that he is going to finish up at the end of the month so he can be with his Girlfriend. Ross gets work in Albania. Mr Church wants him & his team to go & get these blueprints & important items from a safe in this crashed plane. Then you're introduced to this girl named Maggie cause she can break locks even if they're electronic. So they go off to Albania & I don't think The Billy The Kid character is bad but Liam Hemsworth is not believable in the role like when he tells the story when he was in The Army just isn't believable with him I think I would've bought it more if they had Marc Dacoscus or Michael Biehn. Anyway they go to the plane crash where Ross & Hale Caesar have to hold open a metal door so Maggie can open the safe you have this group lead by Jean Vilain he wants what they found in the safe he's captured Billy he wants what they found or he will kill Billy. He has Ross's knife & uses it to cut a huge gash on Billy's chest. Maggie gives up the device & Lee Christmas tosses at Jean Vilain & group Hector Jean Vilain's right hand man tells Lee to pick it up or he will kill Billy so he hands it to him. Vilain tells the team to get on the ground Vilain hands Hector the knife Vilain asks Billy if he's afraid of him he says no so Vilain roundhouses the knife right into Billy's chest killing him. Ross wants to know why was the device so important that 1 of their teammates was killed over it. Maggie tells them that it has blueprints to some plutonium under a mine. Stallone has a great line when they bury Billy "Why is it that 1 of us who wants to live the most, who deserves to live the most dies, & the 1 that deserves to die keep on living? What's the message in that?" Not as great as the line from Mickey Rourke in the 1st movie but it's still well spoken. Then you have this very direct straight forward line that I remember being in the trailer "Track them, find them kill them!" Mr Church gets in contact with Ross he is mad that they didn't get the device from the safe. Ross tells him that he always pulls the strings but you always have other people do you dirty work. He also tells him that they're done. They get into this town where Ross & Lee get into a fight in this bar. Maggie takes this manicure kit & uses it to torture these guys to find out some info on Vilain. They find this abandoned town that was used in The Cold War. A scene that was funny when they're talking they would eat for their last meal. Gunner said "Baby Seal & Whalea  *  * in the summer." He looks at Maggie who is Chinese & says "I would really die for some Chinese." Ross says "Then you're going to starve to death." I thought that was 1 of them more funnier lines that Dolph Lundgren had they really made Dolph Lundgren goofy in this movie in the 1st movie Gunner had a drug problem he wasn'tre  t  ar  e  d. I did laugh when the song It's A Beautiful Morning the next morning. Hale Caesar steps outside for a moment where these group of fighters called The Sangs that work for Vilain. Hale Caesar goes back in & yells for everyone to get down. You have them get in a big shootout with The Sangs Ross gets in contact with Lee who is fixing a truck he asks if they can hold them off Ross responds by saying "Yeah maybe with a tank." Low & behold a tank is coming after The Expendables. They're low on ammo the tank is blown up with rocket the team wondered who took out the tank & who helped them take out The Sangs. It turns out to be 1 of Barney Ross's old friends Booker where they used The Good The Bad & The Ugly theme to me it didn't fit I think they should've used The Delta Force theme or The Walker Texas Ranger theme. Booker is more of a loner Ross says he had heard a rumor that he had been bitten by a King Cobra. Booker tells him "Yeah I was but after 5 days agonizing pain, The Cobra died." The theater I was in there was a lot of laughs with that line. If you're a fan of Chuck Norris you'll get the line. Booker points in the direction of this village where the people hat Vilain cause he takes people from the town they never return cause Vilain works them to death to find The Plutonium. They're going to take a group of children The Expendables help them out you have a scene where The Sangs are in this Chapel & Lee is disguised as a Preacher he tells The Sangs "I know pronounce you Man & Knife." He kills this group with some knives. The team kills off The Sangs then you have Ross, Caesar, Gunner, Toll Road & Maggie gun the last man in the group down I mean they fill that guy full of bullet holes. The Slaves found The Plutonium The Expendables found the mine Ross crashes into the mine. Vilain & Hector escape with The Plutonium he blocks the way so they can't follow. You have a scene where Gunner makes an explosive it doesn't go off where they continue to make this character look stupid Maggie says don't cry Gunner. Anyway Trench shows up in some sort of mining vehicle & says "I'm back!" Mr Church decides to help The Expendables. Then you go to this awesome finish at an airport. The back & forth between Bruce Willis & Arnold Schwarzenegger is funny cause Arnold Schwarzenegger needs to reload & says "I'll be back." Willis says "You've been back enough!" Schwarzenegger says "Yippe ki yay." You have Mr Church get this compact car & you get that hilarious line that was in the trailer " My shoes are bigger than this car" Plus you have Chuck Norris gun this guy while he is going through an airport X Ray Machine. Vilain & Hector try to escape Lee gets in a fight Hector a very good fight resulting in Lee hitting Hector with a pair of brass knucks & his head is chopped up on an airplane propeller. There is this really good fight between Stallone & Van Damme it was originally written Jean Vilain was running away from Barney Ross Van Damme asked for it to be rewritten which I am glad he did cause this was nearly what I would call a great fight. Ross kills Vilain & brings his head out to Mr Church Trench says it's a nice touch. Ross & Maggie say their good byes which was a nice scene. Mr Church got a plane for The Expendables it looks like it's from the 30's or 40's  Ross says "That thing belongs in a museum." Trench's response is "We all do." As they head off Lee tells Ross that he needs to learn how to fight cause he is bruised & cut up from his fight. Anyway this was a strong sequel it did keep a lot of good stuff from the 1st movie with the action straight forward plot humor that was funny for the most part. I didn't care for how they made The Gunner Character look goofy. The AA 12 Shotgun lost a lot of it's guts I could tell that it was shot for a PG 13  from the start. But this was a strong sequel & has a lot of good things going for than bad things. Simon West did a good job although I am sure that Stallone had a lot of input either way it was directed really good. Sylvester Stallone did a great job. Jason Statham was good. Arnold Schwarzenegger was given a little more time & he did a good job as did Bruce Willis who got more time too. Terry Crews gave a nice normal performance. Dolph Lundgren did a pretty good job despite being written as a goofy character. Liam Hemsworth was ok. Jean Claude Van Damme was good. Scott Adkins did a good job. Yu Nan did a very good job I surprised cause I had never heard of her before. Jet Li did fie although he was only in the movie like 5 minutes or less. Definite recommendation stoong sequel. I know their is an Expendables 3 coming out next summer but I am in no hurry in seeing the cast it's going to filled with UFC guys & girls & Boxers they're great athletes but they don't make good actors most of the time. I am not looking forward to Mel Gibson as the villain cause of how low he has became as human being. I know they got Wesley Snipes & he should be the villain or how about Michael Wincott Sean Bean would make a better villain than Mel Gibson. I would rather have Vincent Klyn. Kelsey Grammer nothing about him says action star. Kellan Lutz from The Twilight movies come on Stallone you couldn't get Jeff Speakman, Thomas Jane, Karl Urban, The Rock, Vin Diesel, Kurt Russell or even Michael Biehn. I know the story why Bruce Willis isn't coming back. I agree with Wesley Snipes & Antonio Banderas that's the only casting I like this movie will suffer the part 3 curse it looks like. So it's going against what The Expendables & even Expendables 2 set out to do going back to the old 80's 90's action movies but update it a little bit. Anyway check out Expendables 1 & 2 if you're a fan of old school action movies.
Title: N/A

reviewText: If you watch some of the "extras" after E-2, you will experience s somewhat telling interview by Sly.  He was more interested in character development in this movie than in the first one.  But at the same time, he was trying to spoof all of his fellow action adventure actors -- and there are so many used up lines scattered through the film it's almost torture (see if you can count them all up).  Ironically, what made the first movie so much fun is that it was all done on the fly by Sly -- he literally directed and ran headlong in to walls at the same time.  And it was great just for that reason.  He let all these venerable action adventure actors just do their thing around a loosely structured plot.  Coupled with the edgy motorcycle lifestyle and strange tatoos and jewelry it worked really well.  Micky Rourke's role in the first film -- and not repeated in the second -- was particularly interesting.  I enjoyed the second film, but it's just a bit too polished and too scripted.  Yeah, the group succeeds in blowing !@#$ up pretty much nonstop.  And Jean-Claude Van Damme is particularly strange bad guy.  But the slickness takes something away from the first movies grit.  It's still fun though and great to see Chuck Norris back in action.
summary: A More Polished Sequal, But Not Necessarily Better

reviewText: The last movie I reviewed ("Hit and Run") got a slam. A reader/reviewer informed me that it was a movie for the below 50+ crowd and I was obviously not part of it. What's "The Expendables 2" then? I would expect it was also created for the machismo, teen boy crowd--like, wow, man, shoot that sucka!!! Only this time--and for all movies like this--I'm in! In fact, I'm in big time!But then again, this old broad is the same age as the machismo dudes with the duality of muscles and wrinkled skin wrapped around them! Sylvester Stallone, that heartthrob of the '70's and '80's, is the leader of a band of misfit former soldiers, now a tightly knit band of mercenaries for extracting good guys and executing bad guys.Many scenes are absolutely unbelievable--in fact, so much so, that the viewer just goes along for the ride. The most blatant is the pop-up appearance of Chuck Norris in the the most incredibly isolated area. Yet, there he is eradicating the piled up forces of evil and freeing our dudes.The most fun part of the movie for me is the inclusion of Jason Statham as second man to Stallone. I have never seen Jason play second to anyone, but this was fun to see him in a secondary spot. Gives him new dimension.Someone nearly always dies in a movie like this. I was not happy with the choice, but this man's death moved the action along in a new direction and tidied up disrupted emotional energies.I loved this movie despite its preposterous action scenes. I loved the one-liners and the comraderie. "Expendables 2" is a most worthy escapist fare of the best kind (for those who love their action thrillers)!

reviewText: The Expendables was supposed to be a throwback to 80's and 90's action films, but for whatever reason has always looked like something that, due to budget and location, was meant for the DTV world. Lame jokes. Stiff acting. Dumbed-down plots. You say, isn't that what 80's and 90's action movies were known? Well, sure, but they did them in a way that wasn't self-parody. The Expendables IS self-parody and this latest entry was an abomination. Avi Lerner is the King of Low-Budget DTV fare and has brought that over to theatrically released films. This was a perfect action cast thrust into a poorly plotted, truncated time-wise (90 min or so for that many characters?), lop-sided film. The draw was Jean-Claude Van Damme going up agains Sly Stallone. A "love letter to martial arts fans" as Stallone was quoted as saying. Well, a six minute end fight, poorly doubled and choreographed with Van Damme is hardly a "love letter." The rest of the movie is okay, but the groans really come with the most thrown together, incoherent ending I've seen. All these beloved action heroes quoting each other's famous lines from other movies, many badly timed, and one lame joke after another. Action fans deserved better. Only the insanely large cast gets this 3 stars. As a movie, it probably is 1-2 stars. The blu-ray has minimal extras. If you want to see what extras should be like, pick up the director's cut of the first film.
summary: Lerner Teases Action Fans With an Appetizer of an Action Film

reviewText: The thing I really liked about this film was the cast.  You gotta love the star-studded cast of The Expendables 2, especially if you are an action fan like myself.  There are some great fight scenes and like The Avengers, this film does a good job of balancing screen time so you get to see everyone in action.  The fast pace of the film kept it from being a drag, and it was a very fast watch.  One liners and bad acting also make this film hilarious, and I was bursting out laughing at some of the scenes with poorly written dialogue.  I also liked how this film payed homage to older action films, such as The Terminator and Die Hard, by referencing classic lines from those films.  All these elements together made this a very entertaining action film.  As long as you come into the film expecting to have some fun and not take it seriously, you will have a good time with it.While this was one of the more fun films I've seen this summer, there were a lot of flaws with it.  We didn't get to see a whole lot of Jean-Claude Van Damme, which is disappointing because he could've made a great, rather than good villain.  Stallone overshadowed a lot of the cast.  Also, the acting in this film is pretty bad.  That made it more fun for me, but it might not be as enjoyable for everyone else.  This film was also very cliche, although that was probably intended.  Finally, my biggest complaint is the addition of a female to the Expendables team.  That's all I will say about that.The Expendables 2 is a solid action film with plenty of laughs and fun.  If you can get past the cliched story, bad acting, and overused CGI blood, this is a good action film with good intentions.  I recommend this film to anyone that enjoys action films, particularly 80s and 90s action films.
summary: What the first film should've been!

reviewText: "The Expendables 2" is great! This is how the story goes: The Expendables are back and this time it's personal... Barney Ross, Lee Christmas, Yin Yang, Gunnar Jensen, Toll Road and Hale Caesar -- with newest members Billy the Kid and Maggie aboard -- are reunited when Mr. Church enlists the Expendables to take on a seemingly simple job. The task looks like an easy paycheck for Barney and his band of old-school mercenaries. But when things go wrong and one of their own is viciously killed, the Expendables are compelled to seek revenge in hostile territory where the odds are stacked against them. Hell-bent on payback, the crew cuts a swath of destruction through opposing forces, wreaking havoc and shutting down an unexpected threat in the nick of time -- six pounds of weapons-grade plutonium; enough to change the balance of power in the world. But that's nothing compared to the justice they serve against the villainous adversary who savagely murdered their brother. That is done the Expendables way....The cast led by Sylvester Stallone (who also co-wrote the screenplay) (as Barney Ross), Jason Statham (as Lee Christmas), Jet Li (as Yin Yang), Dolph Lundgren (as Gunner Jensen), Chuck Norris (as Booker), Terry Crews (as Hale Caesar), Randy Couture (as Toll Road), Liam Hemsworth (as Billy the Kid), Jean-Claude Van Damme (as Vilain), Bruce Willis (as Church), Arnold Schwarzenegger (as Trench), Nan Yu (as Maggie) & Scott Adkins (as Hector) is great. The directing by Simon West is great. The story by Ken Kaufman, David Agosto & Richard Wenk & the screenplay by Stallone & Wenk is great.The music by Brian Tyler is great. The cinematography by Shelly Johnson is great. The film editing by Todd E. Miller is great. The casting by Marianne Stanicheva is great. The production design by Paul Cross is great. The art direction by Adam A. Makin, Ivailo Nikolov, Ivan Ranghelov & Sonya Savova is great. The costume design by Lizz Wolf is great. The stunts coordinated by Dian Hristov, Noon Orsatti, Chad Stahelski, Stanimir Stamatov & Teodor Tsolov, fights coordinated by Don Thai Theerathada is great. The set dressings by Jaime Fernandez, assistant set decoration by Nikolai Nikolov & set dressings coordinated by Vasilena Boneva is great. The special effects supervised by Alexander Gunn & Ivo Jivkov is great. The visual effects supervised by Danail Hadzhiyski, Ajoy Mani, Stalin Saravanan & Stefan Tchakarov, coordinated by Kiril Georgiev, Vladimir Nikolov, Milena Peneva, Iavor Radev & Plamen Statev is great.This is a fun and entertaining action film that does keep you entertained and is at times, funny as well. This is also a great sequel that is better than its original. Stallone and his crew is solidly great in this one, with a solid villain in Van Damme's Vilain. This is also a great action film that is perfectly positioned in the dog days of the summer season.

reviewText: Was a decent action flick. Many cameo stars left and right. Some of the ways they reveal the cameos are way too corny, and just seemed like, "Let's just put him here, have him say a couple lines, then send him on his way. By the way, here's your check, see ya later!"Don't get me wrong, these are some of my favorite action stars of the '80s and 90s, and it's cool to see them all together in the same film. Character building and evolution is pointless, and the story overall is unoriginal and predictable.If you saw the first one, don't expect much difference, just added action heroes, and more action. Knocked a star for the very corny one liners (which plague nearly half the dialog) and weak references to other movies/television shows.
summary: Good Action, Too Many Action Movie Clichés

reviewText: I love Stallone's directing. Instead of waiting for others to direct, he goes on and does it all himself and makes a triple comeback with the last and proper ending for Rocky, then Rambo, and then tops it all off with his own creation - The Expendables! Again, co-writing and directing it all himself.So of course Expendables 2 comes out and lets loose the dogs of war - but even bigger and somewhat better.Never a dull moment, Ex 2 starts out with one of the best and most explosive action scenes EVER recorded. The movie hardly ever comes up for air, and before ya know it, its over and you find yourself properly pumped up as an avid moviegoer. Don't take it too seriously. It is a plain old-fashioned action flick staring the biggest and the baddest action stars in the last 3 decades. (Actually a wee bit more because of Stallone himself!)Stallone and Statham make a great bromance couple. Statham makes tons of the same movie, except most don't use his solid acting skills, but only use his action moves. Always the wooden action dude.But Stallone is much smarter than your typical writer/director. He's been around long enough to know the movie audience needs and wants more. So he creates an actual storyline around Statham's character, showcasing his solid acting skills like no other director has done since SNATCH.Yes, there are new and longer parts for the other actions stars, from Chuck Norris to Van Damme, but Stallone has and does outdo them all here, both as an actor and a storyteller/director.I love both films. A must see for any action fan who loves a solid popcorn summer movie.
summary: Bottom Line: Top Line Popcorn Entertainment!
Title: N/A

reviewText: This geriatric genocidal shootout amongst old pals, propelled by a mixture of testosterone, big guns, insider jokes, even bigger guns, martial arts and deliberately silly one-liners, is even better than the first instalment. It was clearly conceived as a pure comedy and no matter how hard you try you will not find even one serious moment in it - and I simply loved every second of this tasty treat! Below, more of my impressions, with some LIMITED SPOILERS and also, quite appropriately, some passably lame jokes.1. Characters and actorsAlmost all of the old cast is present also in this film and it is a mighty good thing, but two of the Expendables are nevertheless absent or almost absent. To my considerable regret Mickey Rourke dropped off and it is a pity but I can easily imagine his character from the first part, Tool, being deceased and currently residing in Valhalla, where he enjoys the company of stripper Valkyries, an unlimited supply of mead and ale and especially an equally unlimited supply of sparring partners he can repeatedly punch in the face, without gloves - and they are all plastic surgeons, something that real Mickey Rourke would probably appreciate... Yin Yang, played by Jet Li, appears only briefly and vanishes after first 10 minutes, but - SPOILER here - no, he doesn't die and therefore maybe he will be back for a longer appearance in the third part...The rest of the gang is all here: Barney Ross (Sylvester Stallone), Lee Christmas (Jason Statham), Hale Ceasar (Terry Crews), Toll Road (Randy Couture) and my absolute favourite Gunnar Jensen (Dolph Lundgren), still as insane as he is gigantic. They are joined for this adventure by some fresh meat, Billy the Kid (no, it isn't a joke), a young veteran of Afghanistan war, played by Liam Hensworth. Later on they will be joined by Maggie (Nan Yu), a sexy CIA operative, who will in this film give Barney Ross an opportunity to be protective to a young lady reminding him of a daughter he never had (exactly as in the first film)...As we all remember one of the best gags in the first film was about the various complicated issues all those characters had in their life: age (Ross), cheating girlfriend (Christmas), money (Yang), drugs (Jensen), ear related insecurity bordering on depression (Road) and a... well, kind of problem that men who suffer from it usually solve by carrying enormous firearms (Ceasar). In this one it was decided, I think wisely, mostly to not follow further in this way, with the notable exceptions of Christmas and Ceasar's situations... )))That being said we keep learning stuff about the Expendables and most of it is pretty funny, like the fact that one of them really enjoys cooking and he is DEADLY serious about the correct way of making his rigatoni and also that another one has got a PhD - and no, it is not the kind of PhD you immediately thought about, but a REAL one, obtained at MIT! Oh, and we also learn some surprising things about their ethnic origins...)))2. More of everythingThis was the main line of action retained for this film and the director kept it this way from the beginning to the end. You thought that in the first time Ceasar used big guns? Here they are bigger! You found Gunnar Jensen a real b@dass before? Now he is badder! You considered Ross bold? Well, now he is bolder! You liked Bruce Willis being bald? Well, here he is balder! Etc., etc.This film has more action scenes, more violence and definitely more raw fire power than the first one - in fact at one moment a T-72 tank rolls in, all guns blazing! There is also much more humour with a great deal of both good and bad one liners and some extremely funny dialogs, of which my favourite is the one beginning with Stallone saying: "We are Americans"...)))But the REALLY good thing about this "more of everything" approach" is that both Bruce Willis and Arnold Schwarzenegger have more screen time and it is used in the most optimal way!3. ZE BAD GUYAs the villain of the story Jean-Claude Van Damme has finally an occasion to do on the screen something more interesting than his usual stuff - and he gives a great show! His character is so completely over the top that it actually helps a lot to transform this film into pure comedy. Let's just count his evil ways: a tall, muscular guy with a threatening face, dressed elegantly in dark clothes, with a clearly satanic tattoo on the neck, talking with a foreign accent and sometimes going the whole nine yards and simply speaking French. And as if all of that was not enough to show that he is the Big Bad Wolf in this story, oh, let's just name him Jean Vilain...)))4. The delicious trashing of modern metrosexual action heroesThere is one great scene in this film involving the background story of "Billy the Kid", the youngest and most recent member of Expendables, in which both the director and the scenarist (actually Stallone himself) without the slightest doubt took a big bad shot at the modern action heroes, who are almost always tormented and scarred by PTSD resulting from all possible kind of traumas. Well, the explanation by Billy why exactly did he leave the US Army and decided to become a mercenary is absolutely hilarious and indeed parodies and ridicules completely most of recent "action heroes" and their issues...))) This message mocking mercilessly more modern action films and their heroes is then repeated many, many times, with a very literally use of brass knuckles - "you simply cannot beat a classic!" ...)))...)))5. The things learned and questions answeredPossibly the most important thing we learn from this movie is that even if chicks with guns can have some part in action films, into some places it is the male hero that must enter - and he must go there ALONE! And no, I am not talking here about men's toilet...This film answers also many burning questions we always wanted to ask but didn't have the courage to do it. What happens when Dolph Lundgren ALMOST has an idea? You will find the answer here. How many Stallones does it take to put one Schwarzenegger into a Smart car? Aye, we got that covered too. Can Stallone shoot people dead with his finger? Watch the film and you will learn the answer! Can Stallone at his age still lift it up? Yes, he can! OK, but can he lift it up in Nepal mountains? Affirmative! Yes, but can he lift it up in Nepal mountains, on a plane, under heavy mortar fire and with just one hand? Err... not sure here. Watch the film.6. Other treasures and delightsThe appearance of Chuck Norris is of course a splendour - the first time he shows I almost cracked some ribs laughing! You will also certainly appreciate an awkward, quasi intimate face to face moment between Schwarzenegger and Stallone, the new decoration of the plane the Expendables use, Mr Christmas disguised as a priest and many other little delights, which I will not enumerate here, because counting to infinity is a very difficult thing - even Chuck Norris managed to do it only twice...)))WARNING FOR PET OWNERS: my chipmunks watched this film with me (from their cage they can see the TV screen) and ever since then they chase one after other like crazy and I hear them go "pew, pew, pew" and "ka-boom!" a lot. I am fine with it, but if you have a big dog it can be more problematic - so beware.ALCOHOL INFORMATION: this film encourages somehow the consumption of weakly alcoholised beverages - after the first 5 minutes I simply had to go and get me a bottle of "Corona". Then another one. And another. In all I went through eight of them this evening and boy, did I have good time! But of course you do not have to choose "Corona" - I reckon you can also as well drink beer...Bottom line, this is an excellent action comedy, without even one serious moment but with megatons of humour - however, it is rather a film for guys, so it may be better to watch it when your better half is busy with the latest "Twilight" marathon on TV. I am absolutely keeping my Blu-ray for another re-watch! Enjoy!
summary: The Second Coming of Expendables - bigger, badder, bolder, with a terrific Vilain and a pinch of Chuck Norris

reviewText: If you saw THE EXPENDABLES then you have a clue as to what to expect from any sequel. Lots of explosions, plenty of gunplay and hand to hand combat from a group of mercenaries who also tend to have a moral backbone. The first film delivered tons of action to the point that I consider it one of the best action films ever made. It was popular enough that a sequel had to follow. So how does THE EXPENDABLES 2 stack up?The opening sequence offers up the action quota quite well and we get to see the team in action. We also meet a new member, a sniper by the name of Bill (Liam Hemsworth). Each member is given enough screen time to earn them their paycheck and before the sequence ends, team member Yin (Jet Li) parachutes out of their plane never to return for the rest of the film.When they return home ready for some R & R, Barney (Sylvester Stallone) is contacted by Church (Bruce Willis). Unhappy with the outcome from the first film, he tells Barney he has another mission for the team, an easy one that will square things away between them. Mission in hand and the addition of a CIA operative Church sends along, the group sets out for a small European country to retrieve some codes locked in a safe.The group retrieves the codes and is ready to head out when they're confronted by a problem they weren't warned about. Vilain (Jean-Claude Van Damme) and his men have the team surrounded and Bill with a gun to his head. The team can do nothing but give in and surrender the codes. Even though they've complied, Vilain kills Bill in front of them before leaving. Of course this sets the revenge ball rolling and Barney will stop at nothing until he gets the codes back and sees Vilain dead.The premise for the film is rather simple but that's never been a problem with either film. It's a core story that surrounds itself with tons of action and special effects. That's what these films are all about. That and half a dozen hand to hand combat sequences that would result in work for half the stunt men in the world. These films are action films made for fans and for fun. And the new one delivers, for the most part.This time around though it feels different. For one the surprise has been taken out of the equation. The first film we all wondered what it would be like to see some of the biggest names in action films from the 80s together on the screen at the same time. We got that and this time around we get it in spades. We have the members of the original cast together again and Willis and Schwarzenegger are even allowed to play with the rest this time around. Not only that, but Van Damme and Chuck Norris are tossed in as well. Norris has an especially funny part in the film. And yet it doesn't feel the same.Perhaps it's seeing all of our heroes from the past aging just a bit before our eyes even though every one of them still seems fit and perhaps more so than when they were the hottest thing in action films. Maybe it's that the quips and witty one liners we've come to associate with them feel rather old hat here. Yes, they are cute but for me they came up too often. I'm not sure what it is but it made me feel that this film wasn't quite as good as the first one.That being said it's still a great action film. And seeing Willis, Schwarzenegger and Stallone shooting their way through an airport, all of them in the same shot, was amazing. This is not an action film where you'll find yourself wondering how plausible the movie is or if the situations seen could really happen. This movie is a roller coaster ride that takes you up and down, tosses you around and then makes you want to go for another ride. It's a popcorn movie, plain and simple, and one to be enjoyed for just that reason.Word is that a third film is in the works. It will be interesting to see what other action stars of the 80s are brought back for this one. Steve Seagal? Mel Gibson? Perhaps they'll choose a different route and bring in action stars of today with the hopes of making this series of films last longer with a new crew taking on bad guys. No one knows except Stallone who's been behind both films. Let's just hope it continues and only gets better with each film.

reviewText: tHIS HAD TO BE THE MOST GLORIOUS spoof OF all THE ACTION/ADVENTURE films ever made.  It followed the old tried and true formula every step of the way.  Lots and lots of shooting and explosions and property damage and only the bad guys get hit.  The good guys all survive without a scratch - except for one - "The Kid" gets killed off early on, per The Formula.  But all the action heros were there: Sly Stallone, Schwartzenegger, Chuck Norris,, even Jean-Calude vanDamme as the villian; with the expected final fight sequence between Stallone and vanDamme at the end.  About the only ones missing from the script were Batman, Laura Croft, James Bond, and Indiana Jones.  If you have an afternoon to burn and want good laugh, watch this one - and maybe its "pre-quel".  Expect absolutely no redeeming social value from this one.  Five stars for sheer fun and belly laughts.

reviewText: Unlike the first installment, "Expendables 2" is no longer out to prove that a bunch of aging guys over 50 can still kick butt. The collective bad boys of 80s cinema are finally all assembled (and by that I mean ALL OF THEM) without pretense to trade quips, kill bad guys by the bucketful, and look awesome doing it. It's all pretty dumb, but then the 80s flicks were never meant to be high art.  This is pure machismo fueled by blood, sweat, and money.  I loved every minute of it.Stallone is back as Barney Ross, blackmailed into performing one last job at the behest of Bruce Willis' government agent Mr. Church.  The biker gang known as the Expendables loses Yin Yang (Jet Li, who exlpains that they'll "just have to find some other minority to pick on" as he parachutes out of the film.  But the other standbys are still there: Dolph Lundgren as lunatic Gunnar Jensen, Jason Statham as knife-wielding Less Christmas, Terry Crews as massive Hale Caesar, and Randy Coture as Toll Road who seems to be the only one without much to do. Maggie Chan (Yu Nan) is added in as the "minority to pick on" who can hold her own amongst all the men.  The only one missing is Mickey Rourke, but he's replaced by sniper Liam Hemsworth as Billy the Kid.  Billy wants to leave this rough-and-tumble life, which we know means he's doomed to serve as a tragic example for the others to kick butt and take names.With that setup in place, said butt-kicking begins in earnest.  Statham and Stallone trade the best lines, and their easy humor ("when I see you I'm going to shoot you in the face!") anchors the film. That doesn't make up for the fact that someone who has been around as long as Ross will fire a pistol into the air to scatter wolves (thereby alerting the enemies he knows are lurking in the area) or that playing a jukebox in an abandoned building might be a bad idea (thereby alerting the enemies he knows are lurking in the area).  The bad guys, led by Jean Vilain (Jean-Claude Van Damme), all sport a devil insignia in the form of a goat - they even hang the sign outside of the local bar to helpfully guide our heroes as where to go to beat information out of them.Expendables 2 plays a lot like a bad Dungeons & Dragons scenario: go out on an adventure for treasure and glory and then, when things get rough and our heroes blunder stupidly into a situation, the Dungeon master throws in Chuck Norris.  No joke.  Chuck-mother-effing-Norris shows up as Booker in a hilarious cameo to save the day not once, but twice.It all culminates in an orgy of violence featuring Van Damme, Schwarzenegger, Stallone, Willis, and Norris, which is as close to action film nirvana as you're ever going to get.  By the time Schwarzenegger spouts "I'll be back" and Willis rolls his eyes, we're transported back to roles that made them all famous.  When Schwarzenegger tears the door of a mini-electric car, we're reminded that they don't make cars - or action heroes - like they used to.This is a gleefully dumb movie.  But I don't care.  I loved every bloody minute of it.
summary: Like G.I. Joe, only with more killing

reviewText: Honestly, I loved the first Expendables.  I think it was pretty much the "perfect" cheesy action film.  It had tons of people that I really wanted to see in one  place.  It was great.I felt this one didn't quite live up to the same standard.  Sure, it had more "stars" (Arnold, Willis, CHUCK), but it didn't have as much energy.  There wasn't as much interaction between the characters, which really had a rapport going in the first one.  There was substantially less dialogue.  The bad guy just wasn't as interesting.  Van Damme will never be accused of being a great actor, but he was very 1-dimensional in this movie, very caricartured, almost laughable.  I thought they dynamics they had for the first one were great- they were very believable.  Dude wants to seize power and install his cult of personality on the island to make it "better".  He doesn't have enough money, so needs an outside benefactor.  He doesn't like being anyone's lackey.  Stuff.  Oh, and he was intense, as were the gringoes calling the shots.  The rescue was a bit more emotionally appealing, too.  In this one, it's just not really believable.  Not inconceivable, just doesn't seem like it was developed enough.Worth seeing, just don't expect for it to be as good as the first...

reviewText: For some reason I have found it difficult to like the first film, Stallone & Lundren's fued & Dolph's betrayal, then being shot & living, was just unnecessary & slowed the pacing down in the first film, although Eric Roberts & "Stone Cold" Steve Austin were effective villians, they were a bit underused in the first film, but with this second film, we get a better pace & everyone this time around get equal screen time it seems, plus we get more Arnold & Bruce here, like many people in my age group I grew up watching Arnold, Stallone, Bruce Willis, Chuck Norris, & Jean Claude Van Damme, to have them all in the same movie is somthing I never thought I would see & I have to say this made the film for me, you don't have to like the first to like this one, this one carefully avoids the mistakes of the first film, Stallone, Jason Stathom, Dolph Lundren, Terry Crews, Randy Couture, & Jet Li all return here, although Li bails in the first 15 minutes, everyone else is in on the action more this time around, not just Stallone & Stathom, & Arnold & Willis get to do more, & Chuck Norris does his trademark character, the "Lone Wolf' type character very well, & you just can't help but laugh a bit, Willis' character Mr. Church sends Stallone & Co. to stop a mercenary (Van Damme) from getting nukes, & mayhem ensues with guns blazing & explosions galore that really take you back to the 80's, there isn't much I can say that others haven't already covered, except to say that even though everyone is showing their age, they all still have it, & reminds us viewers how it is you do an action film, today's studio executives & the younger action stars they are trying to push could learn a thing or too here, this is old school & it is still the best, & it is clear that everyone is having a good time doing just that, reminding Hollywood how it is done, I loved it, I just wished the first could have been this good, if they do a third film, they really need to get Mel Gibson, Harrison Ford, & the godfather of them all...Clint Eastwood, imagine Clint as Stallone's mentor & former teacher, these three have to do a thrid film, they had just as much influence as Stallone, Arnold, & Willis in the 80's & 90's, many have mentioned Kurt Russell, I agree, however I would not be as disappointed if he didn't do it as I would be if they can't get Mel, Ford, & Clint, all in all, this is a good soild action film that will make you yearn for the 80's & 90's all over again.
summary: Way better than the first film....

reviewText: A selling point of the originalThe Expendableswas that such a movie would surely never be seen again: supposedly, it would be impossible for such a collection of career-minded egos to come together for a second time, and thus we should enjoy it while we could. I never doubted that there'd be a sequel, but if you want to think of this as an example of lightning striking twice, it can only serve to make the movie more noteworthy. I liked the first film enough to give it four stars and thus went into this one with reasonably high expectations - expectations which almost ended up being too high. The novelty of seeing a big collection of action heroes has been slightly reduced - partially by the film's delivery, partially by a bunch of other movies having copied the theme in recent years - and a few of the unfulfilled rumors regarding the cast list were particularly disappointing, but in the end, it ended up being a very well-rounded big-budget action flick that - however imperfectly - mixes deconstructive comedy with a varied collection of fulfilling adrenaline scenes.The story: when the newest Expendable (Liam Hemsworth,The Hunger Games) is killed during a mission by an evil mastermind looking to harvest a forgotten cache of plutonium (Jean-Claude Van Damme), the old team - featuring Sylvester Stallone, Jason Statham, Dolph Lundgren, Randy Couture, and Terry Crews - goes on a mission of vengeance to take down the villain and his forces.I think most fans who followed the development of the movie had their own hopes for potential new additions to the cast. Stallone himself mentioned Lorenzo Lamas, Jeff Speakman, and Olivier Gruner by name. The fact that none of these guys made it into the movie is disappointing, and it'll disappoint even more people that Jet Li disappears from the feature within the first twenty minutes. Additionally, Randy Couture's role has been reduced to the point that he's almost facetious to the picture, so his fans will probably be disappointed as well. I was personally appalled that a prettyboy with only three movies under his belt (at the time) was given access to such an elite ensemble, but luckily for me, his demise coincides with the arrival of Van Damme's return to the big screen, as well as that of number one henchman Scott Adkins (last seen in theaters forX-Men Origins: Wolverine). Bruce Willis and Arnold Schwarzenegger were in the last flick, albeit as cameos to help sell the movie poster, but their vastly increased characterization and action participation almost makes them feel like brand new characters, particularly in Schwarzenegger's case. Chinese actress Yu Nan (who had played alongside Dolph Lundgren before inDiamond Dogs) fulfills the "female Expendable" role fans had been clamoring for, and while I would have vastly preferred seeing a more accredited face like Cynthia Rothrock or Michelle Yeoh in the part, Yu is both a good actress and a physically capable one. Rounding off the credited cast is Chuck Norris, who disappointingly isn't very physical: though he has the best entrance I've seen in a while, he only gets to shoot a bit and utter the expected Chuck Norris Fact during his approximate ten minutes of screentime.Oh yeah, Mickey Rourke's gone MIA, too.Where the action is concerned, I can only complain about its distribution: too much time elapses in the middle of the picture without any fighting or shooting going on. When either does happen, though, it tends to be good - sometimes very good. I recount at least three or four lengthy guns & effects battles, mixed with some nice vehicle-related sequences (at least half of these are CG-rendered, though, so I can't be as impressed by them as I'd otherwise be). I was very pleased that there's a scene near the end of the picture where almost all of the stars still alive at the time were caught up in an extensive gunfight. Of course, anyone who knows me will know that I was much more eager for the hand-to-hand fights, and I ended up satisfied. In pre-production, Stallone referred to this sequel as a "love letter to the martial arts," and while I'm not sure this is exactly what it is, the fistfights we see are roundly good. Though the match-ups in the original film enticed me more (i.e. Lundgren vs. Li, Gary Daniels vs. Li & Statham), these here are categorically filmed better, having all but completely done away with the questionable camera angles and disappointing cutting of the originals. Disappointingly, neither Lundgren nor Couture nor the aforementioned Norris are given a clear spotlight to display their martial skills, but the battles which are highlighted - Jet battling a bunch of guys in a kitchen, Statham taking on a bunch of guys in a church, Statham fighting Adkins, and the finale between Stallone and Van Damme - are much better than I expected and definitely above the Hollywood standard. It's all pretty grounded stuff and satisfyingly violent with lots of improvised weapon usage. Though none of the brawls will win a nomination for "fight of the year" in my book, I'd go as far to say that the inevitable second sequel has a good amount of living up to do.Dramatically, the movie isn't impressive but still fun. I appreciate the comedy Dolph Lundgren is allowed and I like that Terry Crews' character is given a few more character scenes, since he was basically a stock figure in the original. Jean-Claude Van Damme, on a roll ever sinceJCVD, doesn't really get a chance to deliver the dark energy he's been perfecting but still manages to have fun with his character, exaggerating his accent and doing what he can with his limited action until the finale. With her mastery of the English language and smooth delivery, I can easily see Yu Nan growing into a performer along the lines of Maggie Q or Kelly Hu. Guys like Schwarzenegger and Willis are entertaining without even trying. The one thing that really got on my nerves about the characters was the nonstop banter between Stallone and Statham: yes, they've got good chemistry, but if I had to hear them glad-hand eachother one more time, I might've put popcorn in my ears for the remainder of their scenes.Story-wise, I prefer the first film, but the sequel definitely has its predecessor's number when it comes to action scenes. Chances are that fans of the original will receive "The Expendables 2" warmly, but even the hardcore action devotees who turned their backs on the original might find this one different enough to consider a different opinion. Myself, I'm already waiting for number three to come out - maybe then we'll finally see Kurt Russell and Steven Seagal added to the cast.
summary: "I now pronounce you man and knife"

reviewText: Once again a large cast of aging action stars reunite for another assault on the senses.  The leader of the pack is Sylvester Stallone as Barney.  His "Robin" is the not so old, Jason Statham as Lee Christmas.  That last name will naturally be worth a few jokes along the way.The film opens with Barney, his crew and his aging airplane (symmetry there) are sent to rescue a Chinese (I think) scientist who has knowledge of blueprints of hidden uranium somewhere in a Russian mine.  Barney is a free agent working for the CIA headed by Mr. Church (Bruce Willis).  Church sends Maggie (Nan Yu) with the guys as she has knowledge of safe cracking needed to retrieve the blueprints.An opposing cadre of really bad guys lead by Jean Vilain (Jean-Claude Van Damme) also want the information so they can sell it to more really really bad guys who want to make some bombs.  The movie directed by Simon West and written by Stallone never takes itself too seriously.  There are plenty of inside jokes that those of us familiar with the actors and their movies will all easily get.  Included in the action are Chuck Norris, a "lone wolf," Jet Li, Randy Couture, Arnold Schwarzenegger, Dolph Lundgren, Terry Crews and Liam Hemsworth (someone the younger generation will recognize).As I was watching the opening sequence of the boys attacking the compound to rescue the scientist, I kept thinking of last year's "Zero Dark Thirty" and how that mission was quiet, well planned and stealthily executed.  "The Expendables" is none of those things.  It is however fun to watch at times no matter how stupid the story.
summary: 2 1/2 stars for another assault on the senses

reviewText: Stallone gives up directing duties to Simon West for this second installment of The Expendables. The first Expendables was a classic in it's own right of paring the big action stars of the 1980s and 1990s together. Stallone did a good job with trying to direct and star for that movie. As he has done with other films in his long career as a star/director. This time around Simon West give us a sequel that lives up will with the first one and at times is more fun than the original. But overall both these film are about equal to each other. I was a big fan of most of these stars in the prime of there careers and it's good to see them all in one film together.For the sequel Jean-Claude Van Damme is the main bad guy and Chuck Norris joins the cast in a cameo. Arnold Schwarzenegger, Bruce Willis, and Dolph Lundgren get more screen time than they did in the first. And Jet Li's part is pretty much reduced down to a cameo appearance.(I guess Li didn't want a big part in this one. But it's still good to see him in the film.) Sylvester Stallone and Jason Statham are the central characters, just like in the first. With Terry Crews, Randy Couture,and Dolph Lundgren along for the ride. I'm glad to see Lundgren get a bigger part this time around. In the first, his character was kicked out of the group for substance problems and reckless behavior. Then he turns against the group for revenge and gets defeated (I'm not going to say how. For the ones that haven't seen the first one.). And ends up missing the action packed fight at the end. In this one Lundgren has recovered from his problems and is a team player. His character also at times is the comic relief. The man has had some good movies in the past. He has had some decent ones that went straight to video that went unnoticed. To bad bigger studios didn't give him more of a chance.All in all, The Expendables 2 is a great movie. it's good to see all the big action stars of yesterday in a movie together. This one is worth checking out if your a fan of these stars or over the top action.

reviewText: I may be a movie snob, but I still enjoy a good brainless actioner now and then, and this one certainly fits the bill (the fact that this is a sequel only makes it better).  All the old crew is back, along with a few new faces (Chuck Norris, Jean-Claude Van Damme, Liam Hemsworth).  As for the plot, there is one (not that it matters), and the storyline works much better than the one in the original.  Sly even manages to work in a few quiet moments, mostly between himself and the lone woman in the group (she's a loaner from the CIA).  And just like any good action movie needs one-liners, this one has them in spades, mostly of the self-referential variety (and are even funnier if you actual saw them the first time around).My one complaint about this movie is that it brought together three legends of martial arts films and didn't have them in some sort of twisted three-way throwdown.Are there better action movies around?  Sure, but there are a lot more worse ones.
summary: They're Back and Better Than Ever

reviewText: The Expendables was a pretty good movie.  Expendables 2 is like most sequels in that it's not as good as the original.  Fortunately, it's not a horrible follow-up, either.  It's worth a watch if you liked the original.  It appears in this movie they tried too much to focus on blood when people were getting shot.  I'm not saying it's a gore-fest.  I'm just not sure it was worth doing slow motion (or even normal speed) shots of a guy getting shot and blood spurting everywhere from where the bullet(s) presumably exited.  Besides that, the action is pretty good and the movie moves along pretty well.  It's neat to see the "old" action actors all in one movie.

reviewText: I liked two better than one. It was an entertaining action flick. It had enough plot to explain why the characters were acting in the manner they were acting, and then it was pretty much all action. If you are looking for a deep, philosophical, mind stimulating, thought provoking film, this is not it. If you are looking for a testosterone fueled, explosion filled, grunting, scratching, bullets flying don't make me think to much, let my brain shut down and watch things go boom film, then this is just what you are looking for. As an added bonus, the actors are constantly poking fun at some of their most iconic roles. It is great comic relief.I was originally going to give it only three stars, but in retrospect, as an action film, it is fun and entertaining. Worth a watch.

reviewText: To call this a movie is an insult to movies.  This is not just junk food for the brain; it's poison.  Poison for the mind and soul.  It's essentially a program of desensitization, where death becomes mundane and humanity is thrown out completely.  Instead of entertainment, we get "enemies" who are nameless, faceless stereotypes fed on a continuous diet of Red, White and Blue colored lead.  This is everything that is rotten in our culture, and Hollywood specifically.  When we allow our kids to view junk like this, their reality is distorted just a bit more.  Well not at my house.  Not in my world.  It's time some people stood up to the segment of Hollywood that cranks out this violent, mindless trash and says "enough".  These films are a danger to society, and it's about time thoughtful, intelligent people said so openly.  To ignore it is to encourage it.  Boycott these films with your dollars and they will go away.
summary: Junk Food for the Brain?  No.  It's poison.

reviewText: Let's be honest, if you've picked or are thinking of picking this movie, you know what you are getting into.  It's all your favourite action stars from the last 3 decades (with a preference for the 80's), including a few more than were in the last Expendables movie.. Chuck Norris and Jean Claude van Damme join the melee this time round.  It's a mindless plot revolving around mindless violence, with van Damme in particular clearly enjoying himself as the (thoroughly) bad guy, whose henchmen have as inexplicably poor aim with their assault weapons as Stallones team have perfect aim every time with their pistols / machine guns / knives / knuckle dusters.  Stallone has passed the directing reigns to Simon West (Con Air) which is an improvement pace-wise on the first, but although the ludicrous action with all those familiar faces is a blast (`scuse the pun) for those who grew up on 80's movies, the movie suffers more than a little from having just too many characters to deal with.  This means Chuck Norris appears as a passing self deprecating type joke rather than a character, and it's odd having Jet Li above the titles when in fact he is in a blink and you'll miss him role.  On the plus side - more Willis and Schwarzenegger is entertaining , even if the wisecracks are somewhat overegged, and the Stallone - Statham duo at the heart of it all still works well, as well as the newcomer Nan Yu and also Liam Hemsworth (The Hunger Games) in an important role.  Scores if not hundreds of bad guys are killed in outrageously bloody and noisy scenes, and it's all done tongue in cheek.Do I seem half hearted about it - well, there's this nagging feeling that with a decent script and maybe half the cast there could have been a really much leaner more entertaining movie here.  People often say that movies aren't as good as they used to be - but when you see a movie knowingly riffing on 80's movies, you can't help thinking that movies ARE in fact better than they used to be.  Having said that, it's just plain old fun seeing these guys on the big screen, and if expendables 3 comes along then I'm not going to pretend I won't end up watching that too...

reviewText: Movie snobs should run away from this flick because Oscar is never coming calling for this entertaining, explosive, action romp starring the 1980s' who's who of action stars.  Sly Stallone (looking like Barry Bonds' lumpier steroid cousin) is the star of stars in this non-stop thrill ride.  He's joined by Arnold, Bruce, Chuck, Van Damme, Li, and Lundgren from the Hall of Fame, and Jason Statham is on-hand representing the new breed of action heroes.  The story is immaterial, but it's revenge-based, and provides enough excuses for our stars to blow the snot out of numerous bad guys, and take us from point a to point b without too many plot holes.Have I said yet how much fun it was to watch this?  There are so many inside jokes about 1980's action movies that this will actually bear watching two, or maybe even, three times.Yippee-Kai-Yay!  I'll Be Back!

reviewText: The first 'Expendables' was a guilty pleasure. Not quite up to the standards of the best of the A-list action pictures such as 'The Dirty Dozen', 'Rambo', 'The Seven Samurai' , and 'Commando', 'The Expendables' was still a fun B-list action film that depended on expertly staged stunt work and an adequate budget to support it. No CGI here.The story line of 'The Expendables' was believable and internally consistent with the script.  'The Expendables 2' will have you shaking your head when you notice scripting inconsistencies.The action sequences in the first film were realistically depicted. No superhero stuff here. The second film will have you wondering how much more incompetent the bad guy minions could possibly get. Can't they hit anyone?The characters in the first film were portraying as a group of aging mercenaries. Although each character was played by a well known action film actor, the characters they played were consistent with the plot. Our action heroes of the second film do not play the aging mercenaries of the first film but play the movie roles of their younger actor selves; action movie stars 'playing' at being mercenaries complete with script references to older roles that they played in previous movies.CGI is extensively used in 'The Expendables 2'. Fake is fake and it is all too obvious. The stunt work is minimal and most of the action sequences look like it was staged for a video game and not a movie set.The insertion of actors into cameos in 'The Expendables 2' seem forced and obvious.  Jet Li makes a brief appearance, does his thing, and then says goodbye and disappears from the film.  Schwarzenegger's, Willis' and Norris' insertion into the film are the same.  And the insertion of Liam Hemsworth as Billy (a last minute change when Mickey Rourke bowed out of the film) will have you crying at the waste of such an interesting new character.The sequel 'The Expendables 2' falls off of a very big cliff and is a big disappointment.  The action sequences are poorly edited. The sequences look more like a cartoon and the characters bear minimal resemblance to the portrayal of these same characters in the first film.It seems to me that van Damme is the only one to get it right. Unfortunately there is not enough of him. His performance in the film seems to have been intentionally staged as a parody of a psychotic killer. His portrayal is the only interesting role in the entire film and the reason I hesitate to award the film only 1 star. He finishes the film with a hilarious over-the-top performance when he meets Barney Frank (Stallone)  in a  man-to-man testosterone induced fight that decides who is the baddest of them all. Yes, the film ends with the cliche ridden good guy fights bad guy fight scene.And last of all, let us not forget the DVD extras. Two particular extras stand out. The first claims to be a history of the evolution of the action movie star of movies of the 1970's and 1980's. Unfortunately, it plays more like a political ad in its admiration of President's Ronald Reagan and George Bush. The second is an explanation of the various weapons used in the film which couldn't help but insert the statements that Nevada is a great state because you can buy any kind of weapon you want, semi-auto and automatic weapons with extended ammo clips banned in other states.I am sure to get criticized for pointing THAT out.
summary: Delusional Sly thinks that this Film is Good

reviewText: This one tops the first Expendables by a mile.  To see Stallone go toe to toe with Van Damme was fantastic.  If only they had done this twenty years ago.  I have to wonder why a project of this magnitude couldn't have been done a long time ago.  It would have been better to have seen Stallone fight when he was at the peak of his fame.For any action fan this was a non-stop train ride.  If you like the genre or a just want a solid action film, this is the one to get.  If , like myself your dollars are on a budget, get this one before any other action film.  It delivers.  The extras in this version give you a history of the best of the best.  Everything from the director's commentary to the mini-documentaries are top notch.  Usually, these collaborations are overly long.  However ,Stallone gave everyone here a chance to shine.  He left no stone unturned.  I'll be there for expendables three, four and five!
summary: Expendables 2 is better than the first one!

reviewText: This movie has taken multiple sittings to struggle through.The cast is all-star, best Hollywood has had in years for the genre. The old action heroes still look good, and are in fact still believable (or no less so than they ever were).The problem with the movie is that it's basically garbage. It feels a dishonor not to watch it because of the cast, but the action is so absurd it would make an 80's action movie blush. I enjoyed the first Expendables but this one piles on the nonsense, and the action scenes are so over the top that they are not even enjoyable. Example: driving with one hand and with the other machine-gunning enemies with near-perfect accuracy. Sniping people half a mile or more out as they cruise along at 30-40+ knots on a boat. Never missing.The Chuck Norris cameo was stupid and just put in place because Chuck Norris was free for a day of shooting.Boring cliches done a thousand times before: men abducted to work as slaves and when one slave complains of fatigue he's shot, followed up with the request to other works if any of them are tired. Arnold told that if he fails to return a guy's weapon that he'll be "terminated". ad tedium

reviewText: This review is not meant to be a thrashing of the movie even though I only gave it a two star rating.  I really like these characters a lot and seeing them all back together was still a welcome sight.  My problem with Expendables 2 though is that it felt like something was missing.  The first film is not without its flaws, but it was fun and bad a** and a really entertaining movie.  (I especially liked the director's cut with the addition of the Shinedown song playing over all the carnage at the end.  For me, his movie's biggest problem is that it's all over the place.  Characters drop in without much reason, deliver some over used catch phrases and drop out just as suddenly and some of the top billed additions to the movie are barely in it (I'm looking at you Chuck Norris)  Plus, you can absolutely see most of the plot coming from a mile away.  **spoiler alert*  I knew Billy the Kid's days were numbered about two minutes into the movie.  It just seemed like the creators of the film, Stallone included didn't have their hearts in it this time.  For me the only stand outs in the entire movie were Liam Hemsworth as Billy the Kid and Jean Claude Van Damme as the new villain "Vilain" (Get it?).  Everyone else just seemed to phone it in.  It was nice though to see up and coming Scott Adkins play the Villain's side kick.  (I still want that guy to get top billing in a big movie)  Over all-this movie was "okay" and entertaining enough for a saturday night home viewing, but it really seems like a dud compared to the original.  I'm still hoping we get to see an expendables 3-and also a return to form.  I didn't hate this movie, it just really disappointed me.

reviewText: Here's a cast of guys that are getting long in the tooth that manage to kill hundreds while only getting a few wounds themselves.  It's amazing that the bad guys are standing 30 feet from our heroes, pumping out thousands of rounds and the good guys are doing the same and the bad guys are the ones getting blown away.  While it's nice seeing all the old faces together, it's way to full of old movie cliches and references to their roles in other movies.  If you like machine gun fire and mayhem followed by lulls in the action and then back to the machine gun fire then it's for you.  It got a bit tiresome after awhile.

reviewText: Some critics might call some of these classic action heroes "dumb" characters based on their past performances with all brains and little brawn, but they've already missed the point of what these heroes, like Stallone (Rocky, Rambo), Jean Claude van Damme (Hard Target, Blood Sport) or Arnold Schwarzenegger (Conan, Terminator) are all about: Kicking @ss.And from the start to finish, that's what Expendables 2 does, blasting off with an intro action scene that's usually reserved for the ENDING of most action movies, just to put things in perspective for what's in store. Most of the classic 80's heroes are here in top form despite their age, and this movie is a celebration of action movies in general.Great pacing as there is an action scene waiting around the next corner, with Stallone offering a brutal, gory tone no doubt inspired by his latest RAMBO film. Expendables 2 has plenty of light hearted moments with a comical tone despite the vicious action of bullets and martial arts.For great, fun and no holds barred action, buy Expendables 2 to add to your action collection.ACTION: 9/10 Top notch and plenty of it.STORY: 8/10 For an action movie, it's easy to follow and fun.ACTING: 8/10 Exactly what you would hope for. Classic heroes are back.SPECIAL FX: 9/10. Great explosions, bullets and gory action fx.SOUND: 9/10. Doesn't get much better.------------Suggestions for Expendables 3 cast are debatable, but I wouldn't mind seeing Wesley Snipes (pending release) Jackie Chan, Hulk Hogan, The Rock, but also quite a few other overlooked heroes of the past make at the very least, a cameo action scene as they did with Chuck Norris in part 2.Some might even suggest for some female heroes, Milla Jovovich, Sigourney Weaver or Kate Beckinsale, but that's probably pushing it for the future films if the series goes past 3.
summary: Expendables 2: Pure Brutal Action with Big Action Heroes

reviewText: Well the movie in general sucked...but found it fairly comical at times. The fact they wrangled up all the iconic action stars was impressive...what wasn't impressive was their acting and the story line. The over the top kill count was actually funny...I lost all interest in the movie...but decide to start counting how many people got killed about 1/4 the way through. I lost count at one point but I was at around 200...but doing a little bit of research...approximately 489 people end up in body bags. So if you are bored...you could turn this into a interesting drinking game. Hopefully this is the last we will see of the Expendables!

reviewText: THE EXPENDABLES 2 is a monument to gleeful movie violence.  To a time when movie violence mostly consisted of fist-fights and gun-fights.  When bad guys couldn’t shoot straight, and good guys never missed, even when firing behind their backs while running, bleeding and jumping.  A time when no one fretted over the body count, except to complain it was too small.Star / co-writer Sylvester Stallone has done something rather remarkable with this series (I know some have said this sequel is better than the first…to me, they are nearly interchangeable).  He’s taken a bunch of OLD action stars (I mean both chronologically AND old as in “past their prime”)…himself, Dolph Lundgren, Jean-Claude VanDamm, Schwarzenegger and others and found a way to play off their “old-schoolness” to make them kinda cool again.  And he’s done it with some of the worst dialogue you could possibly imagine.  Scarcely a single line of dialogue sounds original.  It’s stuff that was clichéd 20 years ago.  And the cheese factor is upped considerably when someone says to Schwarzenegger, “I’m gonna terminate you.”  Or when Arnold himself says to Bruce Willis (who is the only one who actually looks embarrassed to be in the film), “Yippee-Ki-Yay.”And the action sequences are loud and feature lots of the above-mentioned “bad guys who can’t shoot straight.”  And Stallone, Randy Coture, Chuck Norris (looking frightening in a cameo appearance) and Terry Crews mostly just shoot big guns and never miss.  These sequences SHOULD fail, but Stallone has also wisely cast folks like Jet Li and Jason Statham in his film.  These guys are not great actors, but they are great at kicking butt.  Each gets an extended scene or two of hand-to-hand fighting, and these guys are still in good enough shape to actually do a lot of the work themselves, and their convincingness spills into the rest of the sequences…making them just a tiny bit less ridiculous.The plot of EXPENDABLES 2 has something to with…oh, who cares?  It’s completely meaningless.  You either want to see alternating scenes of this large cast killing people and then sharing clichéd camaraderie or you don’t.  If you don’t…then you won’t like the film.  If you do…then you will like it to some point.  I was lukewarm at best.  Yes, these guys can be charming and some of the action is good.  But the dialogue is dreadful and in particular, the scenes where Stallone and Statham (who are supposed to be best buddies) interact are truly painful.  I do admit that I made the mistake of seeing this at home (and by myself!), rather than in a large theater.  I think the film probably demanded to be seen with a large group.I’m sure there will be another, because Stallone has crafted a successful formula and the duct tape continues to hold him together.  I admire his work (I just try not to look at his complexion…not sure what’s going on there).  Through force of will, he revived his own career, and frankly, the careers (or at least paychecks) of a lot of other affable guys.  I do wish he’d find someone else to write this stuff, though.  I don’t need Shakespeare…but it would sure help the enjoyment factor if once in a while, someone said stuff that wasn’t rehashed from earlier, equally awful scripts.
summary: Some amusing action, but some really BAD dialogue.  Beyond cheesy.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Being a fan of most of the stars in this movie, I am biased...very biased. The action is great. Lots of gun play with hits that are more realistic than I have seen before. When a human body gets hit with a .50 round, he doesn't just slump over like in the 1960's TV shows (Combat or Rat Patrol). Here we see massive gore, body parts and parts of body parts flying away. The stunt folks take the hits accurately too, none of that "slumping over into an eternal snooze" --these folks look like they were hit with a high-powered round.Excellent job in the hand-to-hand department, although for my money there could have been a lot more of that and a few less one liners. But I confess, some of the one liners were LOL funny! I won't spoil it here, because I detest movie spoiling. Suffice to say I am not given to laugh out loud, especially when I am alone. Some of the humor bits really were perfect!  The exchange between Bruce Willis and Arnold Schwarzenegger during the big battle scene was HILARIOUS! I am shocked that Van Damme agreed to play the bad guy. He should have because in my book he is the least likeable. Just to have a movie with this kind of a cast is the very definition of EPIC. In that respect it was like The Dirty Dozen, my favorite old school war movie.This is one of those movies that make you saw to yourself, "I never thought I'd see all these great action actors together in the same movie, I am so glad this happened in my life time!"  I am so glad I took time out today to watch this movie. It was well worth the rental and I am probably going to buy it as well.And I am glad I could share a few thoughts with you as well. I hope you will watch it now. Enjoy the movie.Rob
summary: Maximum Over Kill Keeper!  Rent it!  Buy It!  Love it!  100%!!
