reviewText: The Expendables 2(released Aug/12)stars Sylvester Stallone as Barney Ross,Jason Statham as Lee Christmas,Jet Li as Yin Yang,Dolph Lundgren as Gunner Jensen,Chuck Norris as Booker,Jean-Claude Van Damme as Jean Vilain,Bruce Willis as Mr. Church,Arnold Schwarzenegger as Trench,Terry Crews as Hale Caesar,Randy Couture as Toll Road,Liam Hemsworth as Billy the Kid,Scott Adkins as Hector,Yu Nan as Maggie Chan...phew!....along with a good supporting cast.This film starts in high gear baby;an adrenaline pumping,shoot 'em up,blow 'em up,kill 'em all extravaganza.I do not think I have ever seen a movie that starts off with this much energy to it.You talk about your "wow"factor,this film has it in spades!Unlike the first in this series,Mr.Stallone has gotten this one right.The film is straight forward.It does not stop to dwell on any one person or back story too long,and when it slows it only does so to allow us to catch our breath for a short and well timed moment,and then the gates open up again and we're off and running.Mr.Stallone has gotten legends Chuck Norris and Jean Claude van Damme on board for this one,and they are a sight for sore eyes.The in-jokes again abound in E-2,even though they're usually groaners of the highest degree.But considering their sources and who happens to be uttering them at any particular moment,they're a hoot and we forgive them,if they do sometimes come close to being silly.As I said in my review for E-1,Mr.Stallone is no dummy,as he is not only bringing all his own fans on board but those of every one of his costars also.A movie like this is a win-win situation for everyone involved.The story starts out on a rescue mission in Nepal.The team is flying high with every gun spewing death at the push of a trigger.They furiously enter an overly guarded compound to rescue....Schwarzenegger!??? Yes,Ah-nold has gotten himself captured trying to rescue a Chinese millionaire;the same guy the team was after.Well,the guys got in but now they have to fight their way out as they repel down tower wires and into a forest.From there some take to the water,while others hop aboard their plane.The plane protects those in the water while also concentrating on taking out forces perched on a bridge.When all are on board they're finding their weight a bit too much to make it over an upcoming dam.Their sea-doos are ditched and after a few very tense moments,they just barely make it over.On board this mission is a new guy called Billy.He was an ex-US forces soldier who served in Afghanistan,and after losing six squad members in a unnecessary shoot out with the Taliban,and his platoon dog mascot,he decided,when his hitch was up,to quit and join Stallone and company.However he confides in Sylvester that he has a girl waiting for him and wants out in a months time,which Stallone has no problem with.Willis shows up with another job for Stallone and the gang.It seems a plane has gone down in Albania carrying the location of a Russian mine in which five tons of weapons grade plutonium was stored.Off the group fly and they arrive and successfully get their item.However just as they're about to leave,Billy,who has been their point/sniper/look out man,has been captured by bad guy Van Damme and his cadre of no good-nicks.They're forced to hand over the map,and just before Van Damme leaves he high kicks Stallones own knife into Billy's chest,killing him.From here on out it is revenge for the Expendables.They follow Van Damme,which leads them to a town in Bulgaria.They are attacked bu his forces the next morning and the fight isn't going so well,as the opposition has brought in a tank.Just when things look their bleakest,the tank and the rest of the enemy are mysteriously taken out.Suddenly Norris shows up out of nowhere and starts a rather nonchalant convo with the guys.And just as soon as he arrives,he is gone.The Expendables carry on and upon learning the exact location of the mine they fly their plane right into it.Van Damme flees just before this and triggers the mine to collapse,which traps the guys in the mine with several hundred miners.After a while,a wall suddenly collapses as a huge mining drill enters the mine and frees everyone.It is Ah-nold,who announces,of course,"I'm baaack".This allows the team to catch up to Van Damme and company at the airport before they can get away.It is there that Stallone is going to get his revenge on Van Damme for what he did to Billy.And what revenge it is.The film ends as the plane flies off into the sunset and the guys toast Billy.Technically speaking the film is in its w/s a/r 2:35:1 and is clear and crisp.Extras include a gag reel,deleted scenes,commentary and four featurettes.All in all a step up from the uneven E-1,as Stallone has gotten things right this time around,with his script,editing and pacing.Testosterone and action are maxed out to the hilt,as the guys go from one fight-fest to the next.In-jokes abound and Stallone and company are winking at us all....and we are winking back and loving it.4 1/2 stars.
summary: Now THIS is more like it!

reviewText: Oh how I long for the day that 'sly' stallone and arnoldnator hang their movie careers up. Watching these old farts take out scores of fodder is just absurd and pathetic. I could take out 10x the amount with even better action moves if I directed myself - it's really that easy to do.What is not easy to do is write a good movie however, and expendables 2 has a terrible script. The in-jokes are lame, the plot and characterizations grate on my nerves, and the finale is a complete letdown, between van damme and staOLDlone.Hopefully the box office will drop off enough to prevent a third offering.

reviewText: Why am I writing a review of this film?  There are 412 reviews of this film at this very moment.  My birthday is April 12.  That's why.  And the film?  Did Sylvester Stallone ever make a bad action movie?  Don't answer that.  Cobra.  Did Sylvester Stallone ever make a bad action movie when he tried, really tried, to make a good one?  Don't answer that.  Rambo III.  Did Sylvester Stallone make one great action movie for every finger on your right hand?  Yes, of course he did.  Rambo.  Rambo II.  Demolition Man.  Rocky.  Rocky III.  Now you will need your left hand, too.  This film deserves a finger.

reviewText: Honestly the people who watch this film mostly are going to be the ones who grew up watching these guys.  The CGI was not the best it could be at times which is probably because after the salaries I imagine there was not much left for other stuff.  There is some humor but some jokes you wont get unless you have seen their movies.  I loved this because I am an action fan so if your not an action fan don't expect to be awe inspired by the plot and story.  There is just enough and no more to justify the action.  Overall I am glad the made a second one.  I think the first one was the best and its great to see them in a movie especially all in the same one.  I did expect arnold and norris to play a bigger part but I imagine it was hard to fit that many big characters into the movie.

reviewText: That's the best I can come up with - it's dumb -; one long series of implausible set-ups, grating action, & lame dialogue. It put me to mind of an R-rated episode of the old 80s cartoon GI JOE ( I swear, if you listen closely to at least 3 of the big shooting scenes, you will pick up Terry Crews yelling "Go Joe! amid the background noise). I have always liked the work of Sylvester Stallone & I still do overall(with several glaring exceptions), maybe because I grew up just outside Philadelphia & he actually looks & sounds more than a little bit like one of my uncles or because at almost 70, he still looks like he could run through a stone wall; but this thing makes it way too easy to forget that he is the guy who wrote Rocky & acted in Cop Land. It was interesting to see Van Damme playing a villain but not to have him named, in essence, Villain (as if they knew this s*** was so bad even while they were writing it that they'd have to label rather than name the characters), & I really feel that Bruce Willis & Arnold Schwartzenegger have now clearly & finally run their course. Dolph Lundgren's vast talents were sadly under-utilized & Chuck Norris..., well, he's his usual dazzling thespian self, you can be sure of that at least, & it is just too clear that he, along with everybody else on display here, was paid a lot of dough just to show up & be whoever they are...unfortunately, ...& now there's going to be a third installment. Wasteful in so many, many ways.
summary: The dumbest thing I've seen in a long, long time.

reviewText: A worthy (and obviously expensive) effort, but Expendables 2 just didn't have the chemistry of the first one for some reason. Expendables 2 requires serious suspension of disbelief too, but that's part of what makes movies movies I guess. The references to actors' previous movies (and in the case of one actor, his TV show) were funny, but why does Hollywood insist on the glib, silly dialogue throughout action sequences and moments that should be at least semi-serious. There were many parts where I looked at my husband and said, "Really?"What's up with the bad face lifts and lip jobs these celebrities are sporting?  Can't they afford good plastic surgeons?  And they could have found someone better to play Maggie, the female member of the troop.  Someone who #1, was trained in martial arts. Not that I expect all Asian actors to be prowessed in martial arts, but she did use martial arts in a fight scene and it was obvious she was not trained, and she was terrible.  #2: Someone who was easier on the eyes. Oy. (Then again, her unattractiveness fit in with the "misfit" qualities of the group.)All in all, an impressive effort that was definitely not boring. My eyes started to glaze over after several hundred violent killings though, and I was ready for it to end about 1/2 an hour before it did.
summary: Not as good as the first one
Title: N/A

reviewText: I really like The Expendables.  It's great action flick with some of the top action stars of the past 40 or so years.  So, naturally, I was pleased to see that they were making a sequel.  The Expendables 2 doesn't disappoint.  It's great action from start to finish, like the first one was.  The plot isn't overly spectacular, it's a pretty basic action plot.  However, what makes it great is the action, some of the lines, and another great mix of classic action stars.  Bruce Willis and Arnold Schwarzenegger have much bigger parts in this one, and Jean-Claude Van Damme and Chuck Norris joined the party for this one.  One thing that also helps this one is that it has more humor than the first, lots of inside jokes for those of us who have enjoyed action films starring these  over the past few decades.The Blu-Ray itself is a good product, as you usually get from Lionsgate.  The picture and sound are great and it's resumable and has the ability to set bookmarks, which are always nice features.  I haven't watched any of the special features  yet, but I plan to soon.

reviewText: I think some people are overly critical of this movie. Yes, it's not a sophisticated, nuanced art film.Yet the emotional content was there and the story was very compelling. I was actually pleasantly surprised by the script which Sylvester Stallone co-wrote.The scenes of the legendary Chuck Norris are delightful. I also got a kick out of Gunnar, Dolph Lundgren's character, a somewhat unbalanced, frankensteinish character with an affinity for larger knives.The Expendables 2 is a solid, fun action movie with compelling emotional content to drive the story and give a little meaning to all the crazy gun blasting mayhem.
summary: Solid, fun action movie - a cheap hollywood blockbuster that doesn't masquerade as anything else

reviewText: "The Expendables 2" (2012) delivers efficient comic-book heroics with self-deprecating flair - easily surpassing its dull predecessor. Sly and the Family Retro reunite for an action-filled summit meeting that benefits from a tighter script and Simon West's assured direction. Jean-Claude Van Damme makes a worthy Stallone adversary. Though scheduling conflicts prevented Jet Li from delivering more kicks, another star-filled sequel is in the works.

reviewText: Action does NOT come more badass than this, the expendables is a proper old school movie for fan boys who grew up with these classic movie icons of the 70s 80s and 90s, this movie is packed with all the regulars from the original plus a handful of new comers all doing what they do best looking macho and kicking butt, the addition of a bigger role for Bruce Willis and Arnold Schwarzenegger only makes it more fun and they must have used every classic cheesy one liner ever from their popular movies of the past. Jean-Claude Van Damme was an awesome villain and its good to see him on the big screen again, the action is bigger and better than before with plenty of bloody carnage to sink your teeth into, if you loved the original this wont let you down its a chunky, bloody macho fan boy wet dream of an action movie, this series is a one of a kind guilty pleasure, check it out!

reviewText: Beware: Heavy spoiler below!If it were not for the best cast ever in the history of action movie, I might have even rated it a two stars or below. The key complaints I got is as follows:-1. The first ten minutes of 2 is simply the mix of the all best scenes of 1. That's it. No more heavy "blow the hell out of it" scenes again.2. Jet Li left immediately after the first fight. I am not a die hard fan of Li but his absence largely reduced the amount of fist fight, though the small amount by Stratham using knives was still very good. The last one between Stallone and Van Dam was real bad.3. The story sucked. Of course this is an action movie people should care most about the action. However, I could not convince myself why it took over two days for Stallone to move/drive through some rural deserted villages to a Plutonium mine yet it took just a very short while for the bad guys to drive to a very modern airport in a city.4. I knew Chuck Norris was an invincible lone wolf. Yet, how could he destroy a tank and tens of gangsters armed with machine guys in five seconds that even professionals like Stallone and his team got no idea how he made it?5. The cinematography of 1 is better than 2. I guess Stallone is a much better director than Simon West.6. Worst of all, even when showering with bullets against each other face to face, only the bad guys ate the bullets.Certainly, it's awesome to see nearly all the great action stars of the 80's in the same film! Nevertheless, I am obliged to warn young action movie audience that they are very likely to be disappointed!
summary: Great (perhaps Almighty) cast! Bad movie! Expendables 1 is far much better

reviewText: "I'm back" declares Arnold Schwarzenegger mid-way through the Expendables 2 and for a lot of people that is music to their ears. Action stars of the past galore unite to do what they do best, kick butt and look damnably cool while doing. Could you ask for anything more, well a better question is would you ask for anything more of a movie like the Expendables 2. If your answer is a fist in the air defiant rebel yell of HELL NO!, then  you are the right audience for this movie.A lot of people will not enjoy the Expendables 2, you know who you are and if your reading this, you probably shouldn't be. I admit with only marginal embarrassment to be an unabashed enthusiast of this sort of old school entertainment, I was born at the tail end of the 70's and grew up in the VHS era that was dominated by mindless actioners from the big muscled, big gun totting, ass whopping tough guys of ol' with names like Arnold, Sly, Chuck, Bruce, Dolph, Jean-Claude, and they all have assembled here for what could have been an embarrassing 21st century variation of "the over the Hill Gang", instead it is a sort of middle age and beyond version of the Avengers, only it's live action.The story isn't much, just enough to get the guys from one big bang to another big boom. The expendables are a team of mercenaries who are recruited for a new mission by their friendly nemesis Mr. Church (Bruce Willis), who is hanging a prison sentence over their head based around their exploits from the previous film. So team leader Barney Ross (Sylvester Stallone) reunites his guys, including Lee Christmas (Jason Statham),  Gunnar Jenson (Dolph Lundgren), Toll Road (Randy Couture) and Hail Caesar (Terry Crews), to lead them into certain danger to retrieve a none too well defined package.Another group, these ones of  badies lead by super villain named Villain, say it with a French ascent, played by the mussels from Brussels himself, Jean-Claude Van Damme also want the devise. This results in the death of the team's youngest member, Billy Timmons (Liam Hemsworth), just before his retirement and eminent settling down.Now, Barney and his team engage in what one character refers to as "male patterned badness" to find the bad guys and extract a little sweet revenge. They also need to carry out their original mission, I suppose, but that all takes a back set to their retribution. Joined by wondering mercs Booker (Chuck Norris) and Trench (Schwarzenegger), the boys are good to go. They don't draw first blood, but they die hard and terminate with extreme prejudice.The movie is something of an improvement over it's well liked, but unloved predecessor for a number of reasons. Not that it has any more depth or live affirming sentiments, who needs them. This flick is an apologetic testosterone fuelled macho bullcrap at it's zenith. It is also a whole lot of fun to watch, the cast is game and enjoying every minute of it. The script is full of  silly in-jokes, cheeky humor and hilariously bad dialogue. It's more fun than the first film and has a lighter tone. It moves at a rapid fire pace that doesn't allow the audience's attention to wander far. It's also not just purely a bloodfest, in fact the on screen bloodletting is kept to a minim in the name of good taste, but works as a rousing adventure tail too. So often action pictures forget that they belong to the larger genre heading of action/adventure.Stallone does look old here, though, and more tired than ever before. He still has star power and uses it well to over come some obvious hurdles. His final showdown with martial arts superstar Van Damme is a worthy addition to his cannon of action scenes in cinema history. Likewise Statham and rising action star Scott Adkins gets a nice, but too brief martial arts duel.The charismatic Lundgren is allowed to have a more expanded role than in the first movie that showcase a surprising talent for comic relief. Schwarzenegger. Willis and Norris have fun with their glorified cameos that allow them to kid their famous screen images.  Couture and  Crews just seem to be filling space, even more so than before. And Jet Li has nothing more than a brief appearnace in the picture's opening, although so much goes on so quickly that you may not even notice his absence. Hemsworth is an ill choice, his role is underwritten and cliché, and he looks out of place.The film is unapologetically nostalgic for it's by gone era, CGI is still kept to a minim, the boys do as much of the action as their tired old bodies will allow. The action scenes and the stunts are on par with the best the genre has to offer. Directed by Simon West, who has proven himself a truly capable director of old school action flicks with credits like Con Air and the Statham starrer the Mechanic redux. He gives the film a nice flair, pace and affectionate feel. It is all silly absurd goodness, it knows and reveals in it. Unfortunately, like too many action flicks these days it is shot in grey and gloomy Eastern Europe, unless I was mistaken and that was Detroit.Willis says of the exploits "a little extreme, but nice." I think that this is a sentiment shared by the enthusiastic audience awaiting this movie. There aren't very many like this any more, and there won't be again.  A relic of another time, if not a kinder and gentler one. Sly also comments about a plane looking like it belongs in a museum, to which Arnold retorts "don't we all." If they are not exactly national treasures, at least they are iconic legends of what they do, and let's hope they keep doing it as long as medicare covers their injuries.check out my reviews at reviews at moviezonemagazine.com

reviewText: I love The Expendables.  In my opinion, that movie was the perfect throwback to the 80s/90s/2000s action films, with just enough action, humor, and drama, from those decades, and just enough stars to make the movie enjoyable.  Updated 80s action with the sensibilities of today (cameos and Easter eggs, for example).  Naturally, when I heard about a sequel, with even more action, and even more retro stars, I was excited.The first big change was that Sylvester Stallone was stepping down from the director's chair.  This actually does not play in favor for the film.  Stallone brought a certain love, a passion, in the first film that the second one tries to but doesn't grab.  He literally put blood, sweat, and tears into The Expendables, and it showed with the 60+ year old performing his own stunts, and nitpicking all of the pre and post production components.  So much so, in fact, that a Director's Cut exists for the first film (that isn't as good as what was originally released, but still).  This time out, the producers decided to hire a well-known action director, Simon West, to handle production duties, leaving Stallone to lead the cast, but still handle writing duties.  Writing aside (which we'll get to in a second), West is not a bad director by any means.  The action is big, and he handles the many personalities very well.  The passion just isn't there as Stallone had with film #1.Writing duties, as mentioned before, fell back to Stallone.  This is both good and bad.  Good, in that the original writer of the screenplay from the first film is continuing the stories for the sequel.  Bad, because Stallone thought it a good idea to include entirely too many winks to previous conquests of each of the film's big stars.  One liners work in these movies, but in excess, the movie becomes campy and too laughable, something a huge action film should not be.  Arnold's "I'm back" and "I'll be back" are here (as well as a mention of him being "terminated"), Bruce's Die Hard "Yippee kai-yay", and even a Chuck Norris Fact all make it into the film.  I get that he's trying to throwback the film to the good ol' days, but, getting serious for a minute, the minimal use of retro action humor and mere teases of the past in the first film were enough to remind fans of those old school action films.  Too much is overkill.  The one liner, action star dialogue highlight belongs to Stallone though, who proclaims: "That's how we deal with death. We keep it light, until it's time to go dark. Then we go pitch black."  Just enough of ridiculous humor and macho bravado to make me crack a smile.There are action stars aplenty on display, with the cast of the first film (minus Mickey Rourke) all back.  Arnold Schwarzenegger and Bruce Willis get bigger roles, action icons Chuck Norris and Jean-Claude Van Damme get added to the fray, and we also get some young names in Liam Hemsworth and Yu Nan.  Stallone and Jason Statham get the most to do, like the first film.  Dolph Lundgren gets a bit more to do, but the writing of his character doesn't necessarily mean that is a good idea.  Do we really believe that his character, Gunnar, is as goofy as he is portrayed on screen?  Most disappointing is the extended cameo that Jet Li gets, only popping up in the first 10-15 minutes, and then dropping out.  Not only does this not really make sense, but it also doesn't fully utilize one of the film's main characters and members of the mercenary group, and a martial arts mastermind, in the process.  Some guys are a little rusty too, as Chuck Norris' big introduction is merely an extended wink-wink and pat on the back for the 70 year old action star.  Arnold's first big role after his Governor-ship in California shows the wear on his tires, as he is obviously trying too hard to read his lines, and his timing is off in nearly every scene he's in.  New cast member Hemsworth is an interesting character that doesn't get as much room to breathe.  It's nice to see a female join the men in the action scenes, but Yu Nan is reduced to hitting on old man Stallone by the end of the movie.  I also would have liked to see Randy Couture get more to do.  His buddy-buddy scenes with Terry Crews work, and the humor works for Crews, who gets to flex his comedic muscles (sometimes a bit too much).  Jean-Claude's villain, aptly named Jean Vilain, is cool, and fitting for the film's large cast set against him.  His 2nd-in-command, played by the always entertaining Scott Adkins, also gets a villain role, proving that the casting director is paying attention to the newer, and direct-to-DVD action stars as well.The movie is not terrible by any stretch, it just needs some work.  The opening action scene is great (especially the Jet Li kitchen utensils martial arts fight), as is the final airport battle, where we get everyone fighting against Van Damme's group of bad guys.  We get shots of Stallone firing weapons with Arnold and Bruce, Chuck Norris popping up shooting a villain while he lays inside an airport security x-ray machine, and one-on-one fights between Statham and Adkins (which is underrated and brief, they are both great here), and of course, the mano e mano between Stallone and Van Damme (which simultaneously shows their age, despite them having enough left in the tank to deliver another solid match-up).  The action lives up to expectations.  My complaints come in to the added effects, as a lot of the sets look like they were produced on a sound-stage (they were), and the blood effects added in post-production looks cheesy and cheap.  Aren't these guys famous for movies using blood squibs?  And how come the cussing has to be downplayed so much?  Some of the best lines of those classic action movies allow anything to be said, without giving a F about anything.The extras on the Blu-Ray release are similar to the ones found on the first film's home release.  There are documentaries and making of features.  Deleted scenes and gag reels show some footage that was left on the production floor:  some good (extended fight scenes for Couture, Crews, Lundgren, and Nan), and some bad (professional tennis player, Novak Djokovic, fights villains in the airport with a tennis racket... seriously).  There's digital copies available in the package too.All in all, the movie works, but goes a little overboard in it's final delivery.  Less is more, as proven by the unfairly underrated first movie.  The humor works, but when it's toned down, and allowed to breath more than being force-fed down the viewer's throat by aging action stars.  Let the film be filmed as R-rated from the beginning, and give fans what they want without going too far into the CGI department on the action scenes.  Less is more, especially for a movie that has as many action stars as this one.  I just hope The Expendables 3 takes the good from the first 2 movies, and shaves off the fat.
summary: Unpopular opinion alert:  The first one is better.  But this one is OK.

reviewText: I have watched the first, and now this....and wonder why I did that on both occasions.  This one has me really scratching my head.  First and foremost, Stallone just looks like a goombah, talks like one and should retire from movies altogether.  As for the story, such as it is, you can see everything that's going to happen a mile away.  Not going to give you a spoiler alert, since the movie spoils itself.The kid "Billy".....no pun...getting himself caught was totally expected.  Then, as throughout the movie, the main cast does exactly what they shouldn't in the situations they get into....and thus continues the movie instead of ending right then.  Example one....Billy gets caught...bad guys threaten to kill him unless the guys put down their weapons....(here comes "DERRRPPPP" moment #1)...they did...and they killed the kid anyway.  Wow...not like we didn't fully expect THAT to happen. Lesson...shoot the bad guys when you have the chance...they will never not kill the hostage.In a scene where they're running out of room and Stallone is yelling "CLIMB...CLIMB" in a rickety airplane....of course they just climb out of danger at the last possible second...or that would be the end of the movie...and what probably would happen in any other circumstance or real life.  Later, as our enemies pull into the CGI cave having crossed a bridge I swear they used in STRIPES...our heroes crash an airplane into said CGI cave, for which they have no idea how deep it is, and manage not to completely obliterate the plane itself....fuel doesn't explode...the plane doesn't fall apart completely like any airplane crash in history.  A bit way too past suspension of disbelief for me.  Later....too much later...when Stallone confronts the cliche enemy with the funky accent, he is challenged to fight "like a man" and does the movie-obligatory thing and drops all his weapons instead of just shooting the enemy like he should have...or you and I would have...or anyone with half a brain would have...so we can see how a man fights, I guess....and stabs the bad guy with the same knife we saw that killed Billy the Kid earlier in the movie after seeming to be about to lose....so as to be somehow poetic justice.This movie was just roiling in cliches and bad one-liners (I'll be back...Yippee Ki-Yay and many more).  I am dumber for having watched this.

reviewText: I like Statham. And I think it's an interesting idea of Stalone's to get all of the action stars of the last 20 years into one film. It was great to see those guys again. And Statham is always good in everything he does. Since he is playing opposite Stalone, he, Statham, lends credence to what otherwise would have looked totally tawdry. Aside from the inability of Stalone to actually kiss a girl (seen also in the original Expendables), the action is well-done. It's just that the story is barely believable.I know.....who cares? It's all about shooting hundreds of guys, blowing their head off and somehow escaping any kind of wound whatsover. It's ridiculous. But after all....it's just an "entertainment."

reviewText: If you want action, stuff blowing up and over the top violence in a great presentation, Expendables 2 is almost indispensable. If you want a movie with a deep story, keep moving.Video:1080p AVC encoded.The film has a weird softness to it. In a hand full of scenes there are compression issues. I'm not sure if this is because of the source material (from what I've read it IS the source) or the encode. For a movie made "today," this is quite disappointing.That being said, what is presented doesn't look horrible. It's just not showcase quality.Audio:If you have NeoX capable hardware, you'll probably want to pick this up. There are only a hand full of titles with NeoX capability, so for those of you lucky enough to have the hardware to support it, if nothing else you are likely to enjoy the aural qualities.For everyone else, the DTS-MA track, in 7.1, sounds pretty darn good. Explosions fill the room, effects exercise the sound stage and sound about as real as you expect. I would say that while the video isn't a showcase for your amazing system, the audio certainly is for your surround sound system.Extras:Commentary, Look at the cast, look at the 80s action film, a look at the weaponry used in the film, look at real world mercenaries, a gag reel and a few extended/deleted scenes. Over all, a solid, but not overly memorable, mix of extras. Everything was fun to watch but nothing I'm going to come back to on future viewings.Overall:If you want a great, deep film that requires a lot of thinking, move on. Seriously. If you expected that from a movie that includes almost every 80s action hero, your expectations are way too high.If you want a film that is fun to watch, has some ridiculous, over the top action and sounds great, with a story that would do 80s action films proud, then this is for you.Recommended.

reviewText: I was immediately attracted to this movie because it had an incredible line up of action favorites.I thought wow look at all these dynamic actors who have entertained us for years with high action dramas.I knew for sure I would enjoy this movie although I hadn't seen the first movie in the series.The plot is rather nonexistent and the actors appear to toy with the audience and each other.  The movie was more of a spoof on the actors former successful films than a real action film.You will often hear either the actor himself or his counterparts repeat infamous lines from their prior films.I don't know how many times we had to hear, "I'll be back or I'll be back again" throughout this movie.  Then there are the crude references about Rambo--there goes the fantasy.  There are many such instances as these throughout the movie.I also felt that the dialogue was rather condescending and sarcastic towards the audience.  "Oh, dying so soon!  I haven't gotten my monies worth yet."  What a cheap shot at the audience.Sure the audience expects quality entertainment for their money.  I don't know about you but spending $40 on something you're not sure you'll enjoy does not thrill me.  You roll the dice and maybe you'll get your monies worth or maybe waste your hard earned money on a dud--the nerve and how arrogant.Glad I rented it rather than spending money to see it in the theater.  It was worth the $1.25 I spent at the vending machine.

reviewText: I remember sitting in the theatre on August 13th, 2010 on my birthday in eager anticipation of the big, dumb fun to come in the form of Sylvester Stallone's '80′s action-tribute/ensemble movie, `The Expendables.' Fortunately, it was mostly everything I had hoped for: Big, powerful, bloody, gritty, unapologetic action interspersed with pretty laughable dialogue. Despite how pathetic that film often was whenever people weren't shooting each other, the original `Expendables' was still a good action movie because it nailed the right pacing and was able to etch out the right rhythm of bloody excitement and tough guys awkwardly shooting the breeze. Despite what all the highbrow critics thought, that movie worked both because of and in spite of Stallone's writing. It's sequel, however, does not.Somewhere in all the boringness of watching Stallone's latest cinematic effort, called `The Expendables 2,' I actually paused the movie to find out where exactly my friend and I were in the film because of how little action and how much boring, terrible dialogue there was. After nearly sixty minutes out of the film's 103 minute length, we had had exactly one action scene (all the way back at the beginning), and the rest of the schlock had been nothing more than Stallone's and Richard Wenk's awful, painful dialogue. The film went on for another five minutes or so before we finally got a quick action scene that wrapped up with a incredibly brief appearance of Chuck Norris, although I don't think we actually got to see him shoot anything.This is pretty much what the entire movie is. Although thankfully the snail's pace does pick up a noticeable amount in the movie's final third, most of E2 will simply bore you to tears, and given all the action and star power we were promised (including extended appearances by Norris, Jean-Claude Van Damme, Bruce Willis, and Arnold Schwarzenegger), that is simply unacceptable. For the most part, the problem is the pacing, as I mentioned. We all knew that the dialogue was going to be bad coming into this, so it wasn't like we were expecting some Shakespearean or Dickensian level of character development or colloquy. That's not my beef with this movie. The problem is that there is just so much of this awful, boring-ass dialogue, and hardly any action at all for the first hour of the film, and when the action finally does pick up in the airport finale, none of the shootouts or hand-to-hand combat match the violence from the first movie. That latter point is not necessarily a huge mark against E2, because the action in the original `Expendables' is pretty damn good, but given the sleep-inducing pace of most of the film, the fact that we are not absolutely blown away by the action when it does happen is disappointing. Really the only action scene that is up to par with the over-the-top violence of the original is in the opening scene.With that said, the action is still better than average, and I will take anything over the awful line delivery and forced jokes that make up most of the movie. I have a hard time deciding which particular conversation is the worst in E2, since they are all pretty awful and there are a lot of them. Some of the terrible jokes stick out more than the regular "character growth" moments, though. Dolph Lundgren's pathetic running attempts at comedic relief as a former chemical engineer or a math wiz or a super-genius or something (I don't remember what it was) is pretty bad, but so is the incredibly forced Chuck Norris joke about a cobra. I don't know, it's just all so boring and bad, and the fact that there is just so much of it makes it all the more irritating.As for the film's impressive lineup, that too is letdown. Willis and Schwarzenegger actually do some shooting in this movie, which is a small plus, but we don't see Norris actually shoot a guy on screen until the finale, and Jet Li leaves after the opening battle scene less than half an hour into the movie. And yes, before you interject, Van Damme does something cool...at the very end of the story for three minutes. Jesus, Stallone, if a cast member has less than fifteen minutes of screen time, or kills fewer than ten people, can you please not bill them as a "starring role?"I don't know. I guess I just feel so cheated by the whole affair, and that's pretty pathetic considering that the action is pretty hard-hitting when it finally occurs (despite being underwhelming compared to the original). The first hour of E2 is so bad, and it's all because we have to watch a bunch of heavily muscled, macho, '80′s throwback guys pretending to be dramatic actors, when they should've stuck to what they did best and shot first and asked questions later. It would have been better than whatever the hell this is. Don't let people tell you that `The Expendables 2′ is a revamped version of the original '80′s tribute. It's not. If anything, it's a watered down, lazy, half-assed version of the 2010 flick. It feels eerily like the outtakes from that movie, as if Simon West and Stallone simply took all the unused, cut footage from `The Expendables' and strung it together, and repackaged it to make another movie. It might as well be.-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------SCORE: 3/10+ The action is pretty solid...- ...when it actually happens. So much of the film is dedicated to boring, lazy, awful, sleep-inducing dialogue that goes on forever. The pacing in E2 is its greatest sin. And it's a big one.- Heck, this movie gets a con just for including that half-assed, pathetic Norris joke and Lundgren's "super-genius" gag.- Norris, Van Damme, and Li are disappointingly underused, and Yu is annoyingly overused. Come on guys, really?? This movie was like watching `Rocky V' (1990). Sigh.

reviewText: Loudness. Power. Mussels. Clams. More loudness. Over the top and a good time. Jean Claude has a lot of power as an actor...he's really intense. The budget was big for this film and it was all on the screen. A fun ride.My only question is...how do you get a part of a henchman in these movies? How many stunt guys doing flips amid the chaos and fire are there on the film registry? When did they graduate from the street to make it into these blast furnaces of action? Well, I can't really volunteer even...once you're on blood thinners...the roles just slip outta your hands. Hey, if you just want me to fall over on a mattress...no..I'd still bruise. Hey, if you want to rent bruises.....Not quite sure what's going on with Arnold's hair.Can't even imagine coordinating all the action and stunts in a movie like this.And these barren locations with massively depressing buildings and light...always available for detonation....Hollywood is a big bad machine. Maybe that would be a good location for the next action film.Gotta go. Hobbit 48 frame per second 3-D ride approaching fast. Gotta bring a barf bag, I hear.

reviewText: I enjoyed this film moreso than the recent individual releases by Jason Statham, like Safe.  The plot is very simple and has typical action movie structure which was great.  I hate it when an action movie is too complex or deep in it's story that you can't follow it.This movie features Van Damne as the main villain and he does a great job.  I was a little disappointed that there wasn't a more elaborate ending fight between Stallone's character and Van Damne.  It seemed to be more wrestling than martial arts and this was a letdown to me.  Schwarzenegger has his typical one liner "I'll be back" which was cool but it too is getting a little too used recently.Definitely see this movie as it keeps you entertained all the way through.  I would, however, skip the original Expendables as Eric Roberts as the main villain doesn't have the star power to carry the film.

reviewerName: The Movie Guy "Movies from A to Z"
reviewText: We love the movies when the old guys get together: "Expendables", "Red", and "Rocky 24" or whatever. What this movie demonstrates is that it is not enough to get the cast together to rehash old lines (heck it would have been nice to have seen more of that) but you really need a good script and some good new lines.The opening sequence is a quick scene of the Expendables fighting Chinese communists. The good guys have round eyes and say, "Yo", while the bad guys don't...with 2 exceptions: Yin Yang (Jet Li) who is a good guy and some CIA agent who was a bad guy. I kept trying to figure out how his presence would figure back into the plot, but the film wasn't that deep. At one point Barney (Stallone) is running in the jungle, the next minute he is flying a plane? Did my theater cut out a scene?Church (Bruce Willis) sends our group on a new mission which includes the new guy Bill the Kid (Liam Hemsworth) who wants to make this his last mission. As a loyal Trekkie I already knew what was going to happen to the new guy in the landing party. This then leads to a "payback" mission over an improbable scenario written by someone who knows nothing about the handling and storage of weapons grade plutonium.The film attempts to force new memorable lines on us like "Rest in Pieces" which made me cringe. Arnold and Norris provide some cameo appearances with Jean-Claude Van Damme playing the bad guy...not just any bad guy but one with a Satanic goat tattoo on his neck. Seriously?Stallone has done better. For all the big names, this is a mediocre script.PARENTAL GUIDE: 1 F-Bomb, no sex, no nudity.
summary: YOU'RE GONNA NEED A NEW PLANE

reviewText: In the follow up to The Expendables Sylvester Stallone and company carry on their fun conceit of gathering several recognizable and big star actors mostly from shoot 'em up action fare and return the majority of them to the screen and add a couple of faces to this outing.  Major players in this movie are again Stallone and Statham.  Also getting an ample amount of screen time are returners Dolph Lundgren, Terry Crews, and Randy Couture, while the (unbelievable) love interest/ sex appeal this time around is Nan Yu, someone who will be new to the majority of moviegoers.  Round 2 avoids cameos, giving a bit more screen time to some of the past film's cameo stars, such as Bruce Willis and Arnold Schwarzeneggar, and gives the funnest portions to Chuck Norris.  But it also greatly diminishes Jet Li's screen time though he is given one good physically active sequence.  Rounding out the players who get a decent amount of screen time are Liam Hemsworth (who plays the young and alive heart of the team of the Expendables), and villains played by Jean Claude Van Damme and Scott Adkins.So anyone who doesn't automatically know what type of movie this is obviously isn't familiar with the typical fare of most of these movie stars.  If any of those persons are reading this review know that this movie is a hyper violent shoot, blow up, knife, and bludgeon people to death movie.  If you can't get past that description then know this movie isn't for you.  For everyone else just know that there is more blood, more spatter, more flying limbs and severed heads than you can shake a stick at.  It's really quite ridiculous and often times laugh-out-loud funny.  Fans will absolutely love the introduction to Chuck Norris' character.  I'll leave it at that.  The movie is paper thin on plot: in order to re-introduce us to the characters we are treated to the group of mercs known as the Expendables as they rescue a couple of guys.  After this rescue mission goes off without a hitch they celebrate but are soon given an assignment that they have no choice of passing up.  You know the type: get the secret information before it falls into the wrong hands.  Well, surprise! surprise!  It falls into the wrong hands.  Someone gets killed and they get stumped.  So they spend the rest of the movie, in the words of Sly's leader Barney Ross toward the bad guys, "We're gonna hunt 'em, find 'em, and kill 'em."  You can probably guess the ending.For fans interested in the hand-to-hand side of combat and who fights who there isn't much by way of star-on-star action.  There are several scenes where our bad boys physically beat down any number of unrecognizable bad guys but the main character on character fights are: Statham's Lee Christmas vs. Scott Adkins' Hector and Sly's Barney Ross vs. Van Damage's aptly named Vilain.This movie is far funnier, both intentionally and unintentionally, than the first outing.  There are one-liners being fired off practically as fast as the guns in this film.  Some of the better lines that I remember are: when Arnold wants a big gun he goes for the one that super-buff Terry Crews is holding and Crews tells Arnie, "If I don't get this back your a** is terminated."  Dolph Lundgren quips to Randy Couture before setting off an explosion, "Better cover your ear."  (Minor spoiler ahead)  When Li is about to exit the group Lundgren, who viciously fought Li in the first movie and constantly harped on his diminutive stature, says, "Who am I supposed to pick on now?"  Li retorts, "You'll find another minority."  In the climactic fight scene Van Damme tells Sly, "I'm outta bullets."  Sly scuffs, "That's your problem."  And my personal favorite is when Sly tells Norris, "I heard that you got bit by a king cobra."  Norris nods his head affirmatively, "Yes, but after five days of agonizing pain...the cobra died."  If any of these little scenarios made you smile or laugh then you should have a few more smiles and laughs as you watch the movie.  It might not be worth full fare at the theaters but you'll want to check it out in some way.My final thought is this: there probably won't be an Expendables 3 unless they tap some new blood and make a more serious, and smarter, action flick.  These older stars are fun to watch but the conceit of this film does start to fall flat.  I hate to say this but Arnold looks practically arthritic!  But maybe fans can petition Stallone with some fresh (or at least fun) ideas.  It's worth a try!  Put your ideas in the comment's section below.  Let's see if we can't stir something up.
summary: The Italion Stallion versus the Muscles from Brussels

reviewText: Nothing like a bunch of old, over the hill has been heroes making their last hurrah (hopefully). Thank goodness for superior make-up artists and computerized enhancements. reviewText: "The Expendables 2" is an ultimate old-school action flick. No more, no less. Directed by Simon West (known for "Con Air" and "Lara Croft: Tomb Raider"), the action-packed sequel to the 2010 hit knows what it is doing. With bloody killings and self-deprecating humor, the film provides nice thrills and a few laughs.So, the "Expendables" are back in action, with the opening sequence about their rescue mission in Nepal. Simon West wastes no time in setting the film's tone, effectively staging an action sequence that is gory and violent. Obviously "The Expendables 2" is going to be bigger and louder, and that is exactly what we want from a sequel.The main story kicks in when Bruce Willis' CIA operative arrives, forcing Sylvester Stallone's Barney Ross to reunite the Expendables including Hale Caesar (Terry Crews), Toll Road (Randy Couture) and Gunner Jensen (Dolph Lundgren), as well as newly recruited Billy the Kid (Liam Hemsworth) and Maggie (Nan Yu), an agent Church sends in, in order to retrieve something that is supposed to be in a recently crashed plane in Albania. The team's mission goes awry when another mercenary group led by Jean-Claude Van Damme's Vilain - yes, that's his name - interrupts.The rest of the story is, as Barney says, "Track em, find em and kill em." What else do we need to know? Arnold Schwarzenegger is back (and proudly says so, just like he always did. Chuck Norris appears briefly, with one Chuck Norris fact quoted by himself. As to martial arts action, Jean-Claude Van Damme and Scott Adkins as his right-hand man deliver some solid action scenes. A knife-wielding Jason Statham is also impressive. Jet Li has one great combat sequence."The Expendables 2" does exactly what it sets out to do with lots of action, and the fact that the cast is clearly having fun makes the film more entertaining.

reviewText: Simon West (most noted as the screen writer of 'Lara Croft: Tomb Raider') brings us the second instalment of 'The Expendables' franchise.The film is a 'Who's-Who' action movie, featuring nearly every action hero from the last two decades, such as: Stallone, Statham, Lundgren, Li, Schwarzenegger and Willis all reprising their roles for this entertaining sequel. Completing the line-up is the legendary Chuck Norris making a great cameo appearance as the lone wolf.Ross (Stallone) is approached by CIA man Mr Church (Willis), who calls in his favour and tasks 'The Expendables' to go to the former Soviet Union to retrieve something that was on a crashed plane. The team find the package but are then ambushed and have their sniper killed by the aptly named Vilain (Van Damme), who leads a group called 'The Sangs'. And so begins a chase to stop Vilain find the buried plutonium and sell it - with some great battles and climaxes. This film is not meant to be taken seriously and the one-liners set the movie off perfectly.As reviewed in the February 2013 issue of An Cosantóir (The Defender) The Irish Defence Forces Magazine by Sgt Wayne Fitzgerald - dfmagazine.ie - military.ie
summary: A 'Who's-Who' action movie, featuring nearly every action hero from the last two decades

reviewText: If you walked into the theater, or view this at home, please do NOT think this movie has any credibility, plausibility, or a plot that you will get deeply into. Just like the action flicks from the 80's and 90's this movie is meant to be overkill and silly, filled with gratuitous violence. If you want fun thats what you get. Seeing the old gang of action people, and some sports legends is pretty cool, but of course it's ludicrous. Blowing away 20 men with one weapon, (remember Commando), cheesy one liners, (remember all of them), and something that resembles a story (few have), is what this film is all about. And it's just that, fun violent over the top fun the whole family (CAN'T) enjoy, but the older folks should. ;o). So there isn't a whole lot to say, though the acting is normal, it's not bad, at least for who's in it. You get what you paid for, loud guns, explosions, ridiculous amounts of blood, body parts flying around, and best of all "nearly" every action star from the 80's and 90's. Here is the list of "important stars" and their ages, added up of course. Enjoy. It is pretty cool to see the geriatrics all in one nursing home war!! (Except the guys under 50 of course). They still have it.Stallone-66Statham-45Jet Li-49 (wish he would have been in it more, he had prior obligations they say)Lundgren-55Norris-72--(CHUCK ROCKS)!Crews-44Couture-49Hemsworth-22 He doesn't count, he's a kid!! ;0)Van Damme-52-He seems older.Willis-57-I like BruceArnold-65- He wants to reprise his roll as Conan, (I plead the fifth). cough.Grand total age of-------554 YEARS!!! Wow.It's worth one watch, that's about it. I hope after this the OLDER guys retire. Although Stallone's Bullet To The Head looks decent, it seems predictable.
summary: Please don't take this movie SERIOUSLY!! ;o)

reviewText: With the success of the first film, it was inevitable that a sequel was eminent. This time Sylvestor Stallone cedes the directing reins to one of the best action directors in the business, Simon West to bring a much broader and slicker approach to the franchise. Although the photography looks more expensive as the film was shot on location in Bulgaria, I still think the first film succeeds as a tighter fit. Thats not to say that this film doesn't work.  Everyone returns except Mickey Rourke and this time Chuck Norris joins the party with Jet Li leaving it after 20 minutes into the mayhem.  The one liners just keep on coming as the screenplay co-written by Stallone gives us a bit more character development but the real coup was getting Jean Claude VanDamme to give an incredibly villainous performance giving way to an explosive fist fight at the films climax.  The Blu-Ray released by Lionsgate is loaded with extras including a documentary on action films of the eighties showing why we continue to love films like this.  The disc is presented in a gorgeous 2.35 transfer in 7.1 DTS-HD Master Audio to give your sub woofer a run for its money.  The other reviews say it all so click the add to cart button and be prepared for a 102 minute testosterone experience as Sly and Simon West rock your living room till 'EXPENDABLES 3' comes along.

reviewText: The Expendables 2 is just what you would expect from a sequel to the action-packed prequel that Sylvester Stallone brought to the screen in 2010.Like most sequels, this second installment doesn't seem to have quite the originality of the first picture, but it certainly wasn't for a lack of effort, expense or casting. The addition of Jean-Claude Van Damme and Chuck Norris, as well as the greatly expanded roles of Bruce Willis and Arnold Schwartzenegger, more than make-up for the lack of Mickey Rourke and Stone Cold Steve Austin. The action scenes and special effects are just as over-the-top (in a good way) as they were in the first picture. If you are looking for non-stop action and some cheesy dialogue from some of the 20th century's biggest and best action stars, you won't be disappointed.Those of you looking for a coherent plot, articulate dialogue or not being subjected to actors for whom English is a second (or third) language will obviously want to skip watching this movie. This flick is just pure fun for grownups who never quite outgrew their favorite action stars.The only real criticism of the movie worth mentioning (for those of you who can appreciate the true potential the movie had with such an all-star line-up) is the fact that there are a lot of missed opportunities for on-screen showdowns we all would have loved to have seen. Like a martial arts battle between Jean-Claude Van Damme and Chuck Norris, or Jet Li, for that matter. Whether it was due to bad scripting, inflated egos, Hollywood politics or just because these guys were too old to pull-off such demanding scenes, we'll probably never know. The most recent flicks I have seen from Jean-Claude Van Damme and Jet Li would seem to suggest that at least those two could have done some great work together. We'll never know though, unfortunately. Stallone seems to take the brunt of the punishment and stunts in this movie, despite the fact that he looks much older than he did in the original film and isn't quite as central to the plot. As long as you don't go in expecting to see all of the characters mixing it up against one another, you likely won't be disappointed though.
summary: The Ultimate Battle of Action Stars!

reviewText: The first "Expendables" film was a "tale of two halves": The first half is a jovial get-together of some of the greatest on-screen action heroes of all-time.  However, after a rather strange speech by Mickey Rourke, the film turns really serious and loses much of its built-up energy.  In the case of "Expendables 2", however, the wise-cracking "buddy" formula is in place all the way through and it makes it much easier to enjoy from start to finish.For a basic plot summary, "Expendables 2" brings the old gang of Stallone, Statham, Li, Crews, Lundgren, & Couture back into a caper involving stolen plutonium.  This time, however, the group is joined by Liam Hemsworth and Nan Yu.  Along the way, Bruce Willis and Arnold Schwarzenegger stop in to beef up their roles from the original, while legendary action icons such as Chuck Norris and Jean-Claude Van Damme also have important roles.  A lot of bullets are expended, a lot of things explode, and a lot of biceps are strained.Noticed how I didn't mention any actual character names above?  That is exactly by design, as in this film franchise all the actors are essentially playing caricatures of themselves (or at least of their former on-screen personas).  That is actually what makes the formula work so well, as back in the 80s all these guys were "competing" with each other, and now they are all on screen together!  The one-liners and male camaraderie are almost worth the price of admission alone.Why "just" three stars as a rating, then?  Well, depending on your taste in movies, you may like this one a lot more or a lot less.  I'm not a huge fan of pure-action flicks, but at the same time I loved seeing "the old gang" get together, so I could enjoy this one (if not at 4 or 5-star levels).  If explosions and gunfire are your cup of tea, however, then this one will jump a star or perhaps even two.Overall, "Expendables 2" is a step up from the original that uses a looser, more comedic tone to keep audience interest.  Though not personally a huge fan of "action extravaganzas", I will come back for "EX 3" if it is made.

reviewText: First, I'd like to say that Van Damme portrayed an excellent villain.  I was surprised.  But he never fights.  Why the hell would I want to see Van Damme simply strutting around as a charismatic bad guy?  Fight!!!  Fight Lundgren.  Fight Jet Li.  Fight Terry Crews.  I watch this movie to see legendary match-ups with choreographed brilliance.  In this flop, the great Van Damme fights Stallone at the end for about 2 minutes.  What the hell is that?Lundgren got a chance to shine as a thespian as well, his expressions priceless, BUT . . . who wrote the dialogue to this movie?  The gods of action are forced to spew the stupidest, inane, worthless, pointless phrases!!!!!  It degrades our American action legends!The young sniper is a blatant plot tool.  And he fires a sniper rifle faster than a double-action revolver.  Impossible.  Who advised this film?The guys barely fight all of the goons sent their way.  Instead there is a ton of gunfire.  Spraying and praying.  Why the hell do I want to see these action stars shooting guns the whole damn time?Remember that epic battle between Lundgren and Li in Expendables?  Remember that match between Stone Cold and Stallone?  Nothing like that in this film.  Jet Li is the best in this film, but he is in the film for a couple minutes kicking major butt creatively.  Then he literally jumps out of the film.  Statham has a nice scene as a priest, murdering a few guys.  Terry Crews throws a few goons around creatively.  But there is one villain of note, who never fights any of the other Expendables one-on-one.  What good is that?  Don't you want to see Statham vs. Van Damme?  Don't you want to see Li vs. Van Damme?  They really dropped the ball.  Hey, try paying a few famous MMA guys to be Van Damme's henchman and pit them one on one vs the Expendables!This film has a few exciting violent scenes.  It has too little hand-to-hand combat.  It is a bullet-fest.  If I wanted that, I could watch a million mediocre films with nobody actors.This is a collection of the gods of action, and all we get is a silly shoot-out with impossible shots made.  If I wanted magic, I'd watch Harry Potter.And please do not mention the ridiculous and corny Chuck Norris scenes.  He shows up for NO REASON, rescues them with magic bullet sprays and missile launches out of thin air, has corny music, NEVER FIGHTS ANYONE, and has dialogue that sounds barely more useful than a blast of diarrhea.I am so disappointed with Expendables 2.  I love these stars.  Each one of them.  I respect their skills, and I KNOW they can kick major butt creatively with great spectacle.  Instead, I got a POORLY WRITTEN, plot-less, bore with child-like dialogue.  The actors are obviously trying to be entertaining.  They succeed in their expressions, body language, etc.  But the script gave them a tasty heap of dung to speak and a paper-thin unreasonable plot that nobody cares about.How can these guys come from excellent movies like the Transporter series, the Rambo series, Predator, the Die Hard series, and so on--and YET accept this poorly-written poop-fest with guns???????Imagine Bruce Willis trying to take on Van Damme or a drunken Lundgren?  How cool would that be to see?  Imagine Arnold and Stallone duking it out over some plot twist?  How awesome would that be?  Imagine Jet Li and Statham teaming up vs. a ton of guys.  How about Terry Crews brawling against Van Damme?  How about Chuck Norris fighting his way out of a paper bag, if he still can?We get none of that.  We get a glorified day at the gun range.  So, I swallow my love for these legends, and declare Expendables 2 barely mediocre entertainment.  And it hurts to say that.  The first one is way better than this one.  Van Damme was wasted.  All the talent was wasted.Expendables 3 now looks like a bad fart on the horizon.  I have little hope.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I personally thought the first Expendables was a huge disappointment. While The Expendables 2 is far from great, it's definitely a step up from the first one. This time around, the whole film is actually centered on all the members of The Expendables on a mission instead of focusing only one character like the first one did. The action is much better filmed this time and the action sequences are an absolute blast to watch. The film also recognizes what it is and is full of cheesy one-liners and jokes. However, a huge problem with the film is that it drags a lot in the middle and there's a period where for what feels like quite sometime there is no action in the film. I enjoyed seeing the actors all hang out and crack jokes, but after a while it grew tiresome and I wanted to see them get back to the action. What we do get in the end pays off, but this movie really did need more action than what it did deliver. Overall, The Expendables 2 still didn't quite deliver the badass action movie that I had been hoping for, but there's enough here to keep you satisfied. Lets just hope they go all out for Expendables 3.
summary: An Improvement Over The First Expendables Film
